370353: Bridge from Below.author: Zetan
370353: Bridge from Below.text_parsed:
Not that it doesn't have enough text already, but for flavor reasons, I would love if it also said, "Bridge from Below is put into your graveyard from anywhere except the battlefield, exile it instead." Then, to work, it would literally have to exist, then be 'extended' down into the afterlife.

This would also make it a lot less broken; these days, it's mostly abused in dredge decks, and they would have a lot harder time if they actually had to pay mana for it, then figure out some removal to get rid of it. This is one of the few cards in Magic that has probably never been cast.
370353: Bridge from Below.text_posted:
Not that it doesn't have enough text already, but for flavor reasons, I would love if it also said, "Bridge from Below is put into your graveyard from anywhere except the battlefield, exile it instead."  Then, to work, it would literally have to exist, then be 'extended' down into the afterlife.

This would also make it a lot less broken; these days, it's mostly abused in dredge decks, and they would have a lot harder time if they actually had to pay mana for it, then figure out some removal to get rid of it.  This is one of the few cards in Magic that has probably never been cast.

370356: Skyreach Manta.author: jonrds
370356: Skyreach Manta.text_parsed:
A 5/5 flying for 5? Pretty good. Outclassed by a lot of cards, but a great finisher in limited. Except you cant play it in limited because you arent going to run enough colors. And by the time you are mana-fixing 5 colors there are much better options in constructed (hello maelstrom archangel and thopter squadron).

Funnily enough, as a reasonably reliable 3/3 or 4/4 flyer, this card outclasses most 5 cmc common flyers, let alone those available outside of blue and white. Still wont make me run it though.

370360: Absorb Vis.author: DarthParallax
370360: Absorb Vis.text_parsed:
I like this cycle, it's a good one, and this card is actually a fine example of it. it's not going to impress people wanting to build Modern Constructed decks, but it -is- very draftable. Also, it is one of a few dozen cards that helped bring the preorder market crash from $300, to $250. I like that. :)

I give it 3 stars because it's better than most will give it credit for.

aurioscope: Small chunks of life aren't good enough in Draft, but 4 is just-almost enough, when it's matched with damage. I know removal is important, but I like me a Lava Axe now and again. This is close to a Lava Axe with Lifelink. I'm not saying it's a bomb, but it's a card you'll both enjoy passing early and enjoy taking late, I believe. That's a very valuable place to be to actually end up in your deck, as I have almost never had a card I thought of as 1st-pickable in my decks. They tend to get 1st-picked, not passed.

It's a black land-cycler. And black actually really wants that kind of effect, because you need so many Swamps for the best black cards.

This is by no means a 4 star card, but I do believe it's really a solid 3, or 2.75 in this particular set, which is respectable. I'd pick it as early as 15th or sooner, if the pack was bad. I don't Spike super hard when I draft, but I admit Drafting this earlier than 10 is very wrong for the very Spike among you, unless the pack has been quite plundered. When I say Draftable, I usually mean 11-20th picks in Draft if your deck has a few ways to support it, and 15-23rd picks that you grudgingly accept you pulled bc they are far from the worst cards in the set. 1st-5th pickable cards are often Constructed-viable, though not always.

Odium's comment deserves more stars btw.

370360: Absorb Vis.author: SAUS3
370360: Absorb Vis.text_parsed:
Oh baby I've been so ignorant :P

I've started making peasant modern decks with my friend and I had a deck lying around that I called '5-colour burn' that was already almost a peasant deck anyway.

The thing that sparked the idea was that I found out that tribal flames was timeshifted. Exploding borders and tribal flames are the main spells with a ton of burn and efficient creatures to back it up.

I wanted good cards for getting domain active and originally I was using search for tomorrow and rampant growth. This entire cycle was not even considered - I just deemed them bad cards that are only for drafts.

Then I realised that this is essentially an extra late-game nuke when I don't need more mana (as opposed to rampant growth), and that it can still grab the lands I need for domain. It's also a non-green colour fixer for that odd game I don't find a forest :P

(Art rant)
I don't see so much what's tribal about the flames on this art (other than the fact that there appear to be three tribes about to inflict 3 damage to the creature depicted).

Then again, how are you supposed to depict tribal flames in the first place?
The original art, although more easily recognized by most players than the new art, didn't look all that tribal either.

The new art seems to try to visualize the Domain effect though by making the flames emerge from the land - although they are about five meters apart from each other so there's basically no way for more than one land - likely a Mountain - being involved in this spell.

370363: Skeletal Vampire.author: Ferlord
370363: Skeletal Vampire.text_parsed:
I didn't clue in, but Captain of the Watch was probably built to be similar to him.

Same cost, same colour weight (but in White, Black's counterpart colour), same power/toughness, one given ability (vigilance instead of flying), and 1/1 tokens are given.

The differences are obviously that she gives 3 tokens and boosts them, while Vampire gives 2 flying tokens and can make more.

Honestly, it's nearly impossible to determine which is better. At first glance, Captain is better. However, White has more token generators than black, so Captain should be a little bigger. On the other hand, Black has always had better ways to abuse tokens (Grave Pact, Attrition, Black Market, etc.), so any mono-black token generator should be slightly nerfed.

370363: Skeletal Vampire.text_parsed:
He's by no means a "bad" card, but you could do better for the mana cost. In limited he's a potential powerhouse, but in constructed the only way he'd see play is in a skeleton tribal deck.

Whats neat about this guy is that he basically hits the field with two free regens, the bats, which can be sacked at instant spead so they can also be chump blockers. He is the only skeleton with flying, and he can be a token engine.

The problem is that his token gen ability costs way to much for a net gain of just one bat token. Additionally his 3/3 body isn't much to scream about.

I guess you could offset some of these problems with other cards, like using Strionic Resonator to have him hit the field with more bats, or use something like Grave Pact to hurt your opponent whenever sacks a bat token.

370368: Gifts Ungiven.author: Salient
370368: Gifts Ungiven.text_parsed:
Holy crap, they reprinted the best instant spell ever* and it's currently the top-rated instant on Gatherer. o_o It probably won't last forever, but high-five, everybody! .... All twelve of you! All thirteen of us! :)

This card and Doomsday are the most mind-bogglingly sophisticated contraptions in all of Magic. Playing a round of speed chess blindfolded is easier than deciding what to fetch with this thing, or deciding which two opponent's cards to put in the 'yard. But when you get it right, oh man. Pretty much every Vintage player has a story about some crazy game they won from -- or lost to -- a wildly creative Gifts. When Yawgmoth's Will or Tinker resolves, you know the game just got won. When Wheel of Fortune or Ancestral Recall resolves, you know you're probably screwed. But when Gifts Ungiven resolves, you know shit just got real.

This card can find a way out from anywhere. It can find combos in places where your other cards don't even see places. It can win games in situations where your other cards are already itching to get scooped already. It opens up opportunities where Opportunity itself would shake its head and sigh with resignation. It is the fifth copy of everything. Ever.

This card is probably the pinnacle achievement for goldfish Magic. The moment it hits the stack is the crux around which the entire round, and your memories of it, will coalesce. It may not be the best card, or the most brilliant card, but it is certainly the card through which many of the finest geniuses of Magic play have accomplished their best and most brilliant feats. In any deck that can cast it, it opens up new and unexpected chances to be brilliant, or to become brilliant -- a Modern Master? And if that's the principal joy you find in Magic, then, well, your favorite card should be this card.

This card.

This.

*Mana Drain is an interrupt and always will be. :)

370368: Gifts Ungiven.author: The_Trendkill
370368: Gifts Ungiven.text_parsed:
This is a hideously powerful card that has led to many unfortunate opponents holding their head in their hands as they struggle to choose which way they would most like to have their back broken.

Ways to abuse - search for:

- Eternal Witness, Noxious Revival, and any two-card combo (such as Splinter Twin + Deceiver Exarch). Other variations on this idea exist, such as Kiki-Jiki, Pestermite, Body Double, and Reveillark.
- Life from the Loam, Raven's Crime, Lingering Souls, and Darkblast (cards with Retrace, Dredge, or Flashback are good with Gifts in general)
- Crucible of Worlds, Academy Ruins, Mindslaver, and Life from the Loam (or another Gifts Ungiven)
- Wrath of God, Damnation, Day of Judgment, and Supreme Verdict
- Sword of Fire and Ice, Sword of Light and Shadow, Sword of Feast and Famine, Sword of War and Peace

Maximum trolling - the "double Entomb" option:

- Iona, Unburial Rites, and nothing else (any good reanimation target works with Unburial Rites)
- Haakon, Nameless Inversion, and nothing else

Playing this at the end of an opponents 3rd turn (Birds of Paradise or Noble Hierarch ramp), and finding only 2 cards - Unburial Rites, and your bomb creature...( Iona, Shield of Emeria..? Elesh Norn, Grand Cenobite..? ) Makes for a very fast game. Both cards have to go to the graveyard, and since you can cast this, you have enough mana to Flashback Unburial Rites.

This could have been worded a little less broken, by stating "Target opponent chooses up to two of those cards..."

370368: Gifts Ungiven.author: zeniongames
370368: Gifts Ungiven.text_parsed:
This card is just straight up good.

I've seen it do everything from put tricky little combo pieces in the grave (it works especially well in u/b zombies to just dump stuff that reanimates itself, for example), to dropping earth shattering bombs, to digging up four cards that would all be equally bad in the opponents hand, to simply dropping an eldrazi in the grave for the free shuffle against mill. While it was legal I never once saw a "bad" play with Gifts.

The true purpose of this is to give you options.

Early-game, it's an uncounterable Lay of the Land in Blue. If you rationalize the landcycling spells as such, it seems a lot better. Remember, Blue has very few "search for land" spells... if any. Late game... it's still an uncounterable Lay of the Land in Blue.
Although the amount of Counter-Spells in this set is quite minimal, paying more for Cancel is kind of... Well, lackluster.

370370: Auriok Salvagers.author: DarthParallax
370370: Auriok Salvagers.text_parsed:
Wait, are you all for real?

I am skeptical about it's casting cost, but I am sure WOTC carefully drafted the Set. And carefully weighed other conditions, like 'what message does this send about future Core Sets?'

This guy IS a kind of jank Rare, BUT, I think considering that his activation cost is very low, and has a lot of potential, it is maybe what Stoneforge Mystic should have been.

If you lower his CMC by 1 or 2, but keep all his stats the exact same, how much does that change your opinion?

OBVIOUSLY lowering CMC is going to make every card better, but Some things that show up in Rules Text boxes -can't- be allowed unedited or without rarity shifts or whatever. This guy's rules text box is actually very attractive, which is not something every card can say. Some cards, lowering mana cost or raising mana cost doesn't do enough to fix their brokenness or enough to make them good.

MM isn't just for Spike, people.

MM is supposed to be, like, practically a Core Set for Commander.

It's for first-time players, and it's for Commander players, and it's for 'heavily enfranchised' players that will know why Arcbound Ravager is good and Tarmogoyf is good, and also know why Ryusei is 'bad', but IS 'fun'. AND it's for Draft. Oh and the presale boxes on the internet have to be not stupid or else it defeats the purpose: to put product in the hands of more players than hoarders and to promote active playing of a format.

That's a lot of demands frankly on MM, and I don't think they made this a Rare without considering every possible consequence of making it uncommon and every possible consequence of Stuffing this set with "Too Much of a Good Thing."
I'm glad Ryusei is a Mythic.
I'm more skeptical that this Is a rare, but it makes some sense bc I don't think this would be an uncommon in a normal set.

You know Tarmogoyf is the least Mythic card in the set? He's a big vanilla fatty with no Trample. Bob at least is a 'character', a Bad Ass Evil Person. He's got some real flavor going on. If Goyf is a Mythic, why isn't Ravager? A lot of these decisions don't make sense without looking at more holistic factors.

I consider the possibility of this being a Rare to be one of the costs of being able to get Arcbound Ravager as a Rare. :)

370370: Auriok Salvagers.author: Krysto
370370: Auriok Salvagers.text_parsed:
Let's consider what cards in MM this guy can dig up:
Court Homunculus
Dispeller's Capsule
Executioner's Capsule
Aether Spellbomb
Aether Vial
Arcbound Worker
Bonesplitter
Chalice of the Void
Engineered Explosives
Lotus Bloom
Paradise Mantle
Pyrite Spellbomb
Relic of Progenitus
Runed Stalactite

He might be pretty underwhelming at first glance, but he's a huge combo enabler, allowing for reuse of creatures, repeat draw, burn, removal, bounce, etc. And all of this is very much possible with the use of a handful of commons. From a drafting standpoint, this guy turns a pile of commons into a pile of gems. A reusable spellbomb/capsule is the BEST kind of spellbomb/capsule.

Not to mention he's a solid beatstick that requires no tapping, so he can attack or block when necessary.

Still, would rather get Jhoira...

370370: Auriok Salvagers.author: Ferlord
370370: Auriok Salvagers.text_parsed:
I'm going to make this quick and easy to understand.

This set was made for Drafting or Limited.

If you draft this and any of the other low-cost common/uncommon artifacts (Pyrite Spellbomb and Executioner's Capsule particularly), you'd have a continuous means of destroying creatures and/or dealing damage. In limited, that is beyond amazing. Your opponent has to somehow exile the artifact and also kill the Salvager.

If this was uncommon, drafts would become one-sided. Even though drafting some huge rare is also one-sided, you can usually only get 1 of that card. I've seen people (myself included) drafting 3-4 of the same uncommons. That's just amazing.

370370: Auriok Salvagers.author: SAUS3
370370: Auriok Salvagers.text_parsed:
This is the problem with modern masters.

Your rare could be $100, or it could be $0.50.

I like the idea of the set and it definitely brought great accessibility to some really good old cards, but you can get screwed really badly. It's all or nothing. Not enough middle ground (at least for the rare slot).

Anyways, this card is still cool, and it would definitely break drafts if it was still uncommon.

3.5/5

370373: Cenn's Enlistment.author: DarthParallax
370373: Cenn's Enlistment.text_parsed:
babaker: it's kind of dorky art. It's actually not bad if you like Magic looking pretty cartoony. It's fairly legit for a cartoon-style art. But people tend to go more for post-modern-looking hyper-realistic art or crude antiquity looks-really-ancient-and-powerful artwork.

Also, Retrace may play well, but it reads bad. It's not an ability I have a lot of experience using. It looks at first like the price is too high. Obviously, if it's in Modern Masters, I'm probably just wrong. But it does read poorly. It's not very 'sexy'.

370373: Cenn's Enlistment.author: psychichobo
370373: Cenn's Enlistment.text_parsed:
Retrace is basically a means of converting dead land draws into useful spells. Even when they're a bit expensive, their repeatable use makes them terrifying.

This, for example, would be very useful in Soldier decks. Annoying doesn't synergise with Gaddock Teeg, but there's other ways to do Kithkin decks.

It's not bad, but it does have competition.

370375: Tidehollow Sculler.author: blurrymadness
370375: Tidehollow Sculler.text_parsed:
If running him in zombies, consider carrion feeder as a way to perma-exile the card in their hand. It'll usually be worth it; since you'll still be swinging for 2 that turn with the feeder, and you can always just recur this guy and do it again.

Another fun card to play with is Phyrexian Tower. Drop him T2 with a little acceleration, then eat him in response to his first ability to get your double black while exiling their card.

However, this guy is good enough without tricks to get the job done.

370379: Knight of the Reliquary.author: lungsoftheocean
370379: Knight of the Reliquary.text_parsed:
So happy to see the original art return.

Knight of the Reliquary is hands down in my top 5 cards ever. Killer artwork, completely absurd ability, and so much finesse and flavor that I could just puke fetchlands.

She is good at so many things. Mana fixing is just the beginning. Lotus Cobra+Fetchlands+KOTR is perhaps one of the most beautiful and simple mana interactions available in all of MTG.

Block->tap to sack a land-bring out a Ghost Quarter->sack the Quarter and another land=KOTR suddenly becomes 3 power more formidable than before. Have a Lotus Cobra in play when all of this is going down? Even better.

Lands that enter the battlefield tapped are also no longer an issue. Wait until the end of your opponents turn to activate the Knight, grab a Celestial Colonade, untap and swing. Or wait until they are foolish enough to waste a Path or Bolt and fetch a Sejiri Steppe in response.

There are just so many fantastic ways to utilize KOTR that she keeps surprising everyone.

Absolutely brutal.

Run next to Nihilith, and Korlash. Korlash for fast mana and board advantage, creatures like bloodghast, undying or persist creatures, gravecrawler, etc.., nihilith to dodge the carnage and come out to beat your opponent down.

Casting this turn 5 with accel or turn 6 without it is effective. If you use mana artifacts this can also be powered out thusly, giving you mana when your opponent does not have it (similar to Mana Vortex and Winter Orb)

370384: Extirpate.author: blurrymadness
370384: Extirpate.text_parsed:
I didn't know this was reprinted! *omgasm*

One of my favorite cards but I could never afford the $10-a-piece pricetag. I still will usually use Surgical Extraction instead (for reasons detailed on that card. The primary detail being that it hoses T0 wins against Oops decks and causes no tempo loss. It also works better with cabal therapy)

That out of the way, this is a grand way to make sure what you hit gets hit, so what you want gone *is definitely gone.* It is better in the oops matchup if you get a chance to lay out mana (50% chance)

370387: Doubling Season.author: Ferlord
370387: Doubling Season.text_parsed:
It's nice that a few cards like this were printed in the Judge promo art. From what I can remember, I think Rift Bolt was as well.

Doubling Season is by no means the prefect card. If you were playing a burn deck, this would be a waste of 5 mana, whether you were playing Shrine of Burning Rage or not.

However, there are so few decks that CAN'T abuse this. This card gives your planeswalker's double their counters. AS IN, you could play Elspeth, Knight-Errant, get 8 counters instead of 4, and ultimate IMMEDIATELY. All we need is for her to be printed in the same set for that to happen... (:D). And remember, that's not even considering any Ghave, Forgotten Ancient or Vigor bulldookie.

This is one of the most dangerous spells in the game, hands down. If you see this in a deck, you KNOW they'll have something that abuses it.

370387: Doubling Season.author: sweetgab
370387: Doubling Season.text_parsed:
What's the best planeswalker to cast when you have Doubling Season? I think it would be Jace, Architect of Thought. Activate -8, search their library for best spell and your library for another Jace, AoT, then repeat til your deck has no more Jace, and that's when you search for Nicol Bolas.

In summary, 2UU gets you 3-4 best spells from your opponent's deck which you can cast immediately, plus Nicol Bolas's ultimate (plus a Nicol Bolas sitting at 1 loyalty).

You now have over 6.6x10^619 Doubling Seasons. They are all most certainly 5/5s.

If you flashback the Cackling Counterpart...

370391: Drag Down.author: DarthParallax
370391: Drag Down.text_parsed: I think -4/-4 is where I want "Black -/-" effects to sit at. Drag Down wasn't good enough. Last Gasp is nice. Grasp of Darkness seems about perfect, and Dismember is too good and we all know it. A single Phyrexian mana symbol can sometimes be fair/and make a card cool. A bunch of Phyrexian mana symbols on one card starts to defeat/undermine the CMC of the card. I'm surprised they kept that Dragon pretty fair. Moreover though, multiple P-symbols REALLY undermines the Color Identity of cards, which is the second thing Mana Costs give. That Dragon is slightly wrong to be so easily played in U/W decks. Dismember is abrasively wrong to be so easily played in GREEN-WHITE decks.
370391: Drag Down.text_posted: I think -4/-4 is where I want "Black -/-" effects to sit at. Drag Down wasn't good enough. Last Gasp is nice. [autocard]Grasp of Darkness[/autocard] seems about perfect, and [autocard]Dismember[/autocard] is too good and we all know it. A single Phyrexian mana symbol can sometimes be fair/and make a card cool. A bunch of Phyrexian mana symbols on one card starts to defeat/undermine the CMC of the card. I'm surprised they kept that Dragon pretty fair. Moreover though, multiple P-symbols REALLY undermines the Color Identity of cards, which is the second thing Mana Costs give. That Dragon is slightly wrong to be so easily played in U/W decks. Dismember is [b]abrasively[/b] wrong to be so easily played in GREEN-WHITE decks.

This card won me the game in modern masters draft, with tons of saprolings you you can tap them with this, sac them with the white fungus and swing for the win, this really shines because you can utilize the tokens that just came out and you can't attack with to tap down fliers and other creatures that are difficult to block.

370399: Thundercloud Shaman.author: psychichobo
370399: Thundercloud Shaman.text_parsed:
Well, they wanted to go with the tribes that aren't really around today - at the moment, it's the leftovers of the Innistrad Block, plus upcoming Slivers. Also possibly Soldiers too, and of course Elves and Goblins.

I think reprinting some of the harder to get tribal cards helps with people building those decks - I mean, this guy is clearly a tremendous part of the Giant tribe, he's a one-sided boardwiping fatty. Run some green in your Giants to get the speed going and this guy will slap apart the faster, cheaper tribes like Vamps or Goblins and leave them at a serious tempo disadvantage. Giants are a very underappreciated tribe too, so it's possible they wanted to give people who can't be bothered splashing the money for the Vamp/Goblin/Elf/Zombie Lords something to try out.

It's either hate rating or outright confusion.

This + Dredge + A varied deck = ~5/6 for two mana.

No, you are NOT meant to play it right away.

Yes, cheap power is all that it is.

Do you not realise just how good that is?

370404: Tarmogoyf.author: Cyberium
370404: Tarmogoyf.text_parsed:
When this card was printed in Future Sight, I commented that Tarmogoyf would never be reprinted due to its degenerating power level, much like Jace, the Mind Sculptor.

Logically speaking, I was right, but I underestimated the popularity of Modern format that eventually made Wizards reprint Tarmogoyf. Sometimes profit has to be top priority, same reason why Jace wasn't banned till the end of the season before his set was rotated out. Countless people bought a whole box of Worldwake just to find a copy of Jace, imagine the surplus for Wizards.

370404: Tarmogoyf.author: sweetgab
370404: Tarmogoyf.text_parsed:
Printing Modern Masters have two effects on price of Goyf:

1. There's more supply.

2. There's also more demand, because Modern Masters is going to popularize the format.

Ironically, there's so much anticipation of point #2 above that the price of Goyf stays at the same level (~$115), which might in turn make Modern not so popular a format again(due to high costs).

There's one simple solution on Wizard's part: print enough Modern Masters until the price of Goyf drops to about $50. I think this was the idea with the set to begin with, that is the reduce price of staples so the format becomes more accessible. Since Wizards can make a lot of money by printing more MM (in moderate amounts, say comparable to RtR), I don't see why not. The players and the format will benefit, while the investors will adjust anyways.

370404: Tarmogoyf.author: absreim
370404: Tarmogoyf.text_parsed:
One of the best creatures ever printed, but doesn't belong in every deck running green.

Best when paired with black discard spells and/or blue cantrips so it can grow to a significant size in the early game.

In some G/W and Bant builds this is card is a poor choice, often being just a 0/1 on turn 2 and doesn't go beyond 1 or 2 power for a long time because White removal tends to exile instead of putting permanents in a graveyard.

370404: Tarmogoyf.author: Taudisban
370404: Tarmogoyf.text_parsed:
I can see this is already somewhat degenerating into certain inaccuracies, so let me clarify:

You don't play 'Goyf in dredge or selfmill. I mean, you could, but there a better reanimator targets for dredge and bigger creatures for selfmill.

'Goyf goes into any deck with fetchlands and instants or sorceries you might want to cast. It is not unusual for a Tarmogoyf to be a 3/4 on turn 2 and you can pretty much expect it to be consistently a 4/5 or 5/6 on the turns past that. Essentially, the 'Goyf is bigger than average early in the game and scales appropriately into the late game.

370404: Tarmogoyf.author: GrimjawxRULES
370404: Tarmogoyf.text_parsed:
Dies to Doomblade, so it obviously can't be that good.

On a more serious note, I agree that "basic", "snow" and "legendary" should count as card types too. One could make the argument that they're "add-on" super types, but having inconsistencies like that isn't good for the game, especially because other cards refer to "legendary", "basic" and "snow"-type cards just as they would instants, creatures, artifacts etc.

On the other hand, making Tarmogoyf count all of the card types would only make it that much stronger. But then again, it's Wizard's own fault for printing cards and then doing power errata like that.

370404: Tarmogoyf.author: ZealousEntropy
370404: Tarmogoyf.text_parsed:
The reason Tribal needs to exist as a card type instead of a supertype is to allow creature subtypes on noncreature cards.

You'll notice that other noncreature cards have subtypes as well (e.g. Mountain, Curse, Aura, Equipment, Trap, Shrine, Urza's Tower, Chandra), but never creature subtypes (Goblin, Elf). Each of these is tied specifically to their corresponding card type, which is necessary because otherwise it would be difficult to keep track of/remember/distinguish which was which. We all know that Equipment isn't a creature type, but if someone plays March of the Machines with a bunch of Equipment and Coat of Arms in play, the newer player might think the Equipment gets the bonus.

Tribal cards will always be associated with creature types (the same way Arcane is associated with spells, Equipment with Artifacts, Chandra with Planeswalker). It can't be a supertype because subtypes aren't associated with Supertypes, although I can understand why so many people think it is--the word is an adjective, just like "Legendary".

If it helps, pretend Tribal was called "Tribe" and compare it to Artifact Creatures. Both are card types despite "artifact" not being actually grammatically correct (in English, we'd say "Artificial").

tl;dr: i) Tribal is required for noncreatures to have creature types, and ii) the rules won't allow for Tribal to be a Supertype. I hope that helped.

370404: Tarmogoyf.author: songmage
370404: Tarmogoyf.text_parsed:
No creature is worth $175. I would expect a card of that value to demolish its opponent. With the sheer amount of early/late-game creature removal out there, that's just not happening. Something fishy is going on.

Red? direct damage early-on, maybe toxic iguanar.
White? Pacifism/reprisal/wrath
Blue? Counter, or simply ignore it with fog bank
Green? Bigger/faster creatures.
Black? There's not a card in back that's printed that doesn't kill this thing.

I'm far from saying this thing is worthless. It will certainly have to be dealt-with and underestimating it can be your doom, but c'mon. If a playset is going to cost $600, it's instantly not even a card.

370404: Tarmogoyf.author: Jedijoe
370404: Tarmogoyf.text_parsed:
I love Tarmogoyf. He is up there with many favorites that I highly value and enjoy. He is amazing in all he does. In the right deck he can easily start demolishing on turn three. He is big, splashable, and fun, even late game, you still get a hefty beater for only two mana. That is pretty cool, and deserves a spot in many constructed decks,for what he can do, is just cause a powerful presence on the field when he hits.

That being said...

Tarmogoyf, as amazing as he is, is NOT worth as much money as he is now, being $200 on StarCity Games atthe time of this posting. Do not get me wrong, he is not to be underestimated and is highly impressive, however, he is not that much at all as he should be on the secondary market. Many players new to Modern, or simply trying to make it into the format competitively cannot do so because of collectors and others whom are simply looking to make bank with this card.

The only reason I can see people spending that much on him is if he was put in Legacy Deck. As I am only trying to get a copy of one for my cube, it is terrible for someone like me trying to get just a single copy.

I may sound hypocritical, but if I spent that much on him, then yes, I would not be happy to see him drop too for he was a major asset to my collection. However, I just do not believe that he should have ever got that high to begin with.

I rate this card 5 stars for being the impressive, combo card/beater that he is, for I only rate cards as such for their strength and abilities in the game, but I disrespect the value that many have put him as. People have become greedy.

For tarmogoyf to be effective you have to have the right deck, the right draw and the right strategy.... I'll gladly take them for free or under $30 though.

Otherwise he is next to useless, what if I told you it were possible to cast Jund Hackblades for 2mana that come into play as a 9/8 with haste? Is he now worth $175+ as well? Same weaknesses as the aforementioned tarmogoyf, same mana cost, equally deadly. Also just like Tarmogoyf, his badassery depends on a lot of other cards to make him a beast. So if you think he's worth the money, by all means pay for it. Hell even in standard you can have a 10/10 with double strike, lifelink and trample all while giving your creature protection from a color on turn 4. Point being with all the options out there, there's no way it's worth that much money.


I'll gladly take them for free or under $30 though.

370404: Tarmogoyf.author: OlvynChuru
370404: Tarmogoyf.text_parsed: I've noticed that some people seem to think that just because Tarmogoyf can be dealt with and because it doesn't always win the game by itself, it's not that overpowered. The thing that I think people are forgetting is, how powerful should a TWO-DROP be? Although Tarmogoyf doesn't always win the game by itself, since when should a two-drop win the game by itself even a small amount of times? A two drop should pretty much never ever win the game by itself. That is why Umezawa's Jitte is banned. Yes, sometimes the opponent can just use some artifact removal on the jitte, but many other times it will go unanswered and just dominate the whole game. You know a two-drop is overpowered when an excuse that people give to call it balanced is "it doesn't always make you win the game."

370404: Tarmogoyf.author: infernox10
370404: Tarmogoyf.text_parsed:
For people not understanding why Tarmogoyf is powerful:

Tarmogoyf doesn't "break" the game by any means.
However, for just , you get a card that gets better by just playing Magic: The Gathering.
If you play, say, Noble Hierarch off of a cracked Misty Rainforest on turn one, your opponent Lightning Bolts him on his turn, and you follow with a land and Tarmogoyf, you now have a 3/4 for .
That's common. You need no combos. You need hardly any interaction. You need to just pay the mana cost and swing till your opponent removes it.

370404: Tarmogoyf.author: Drewskithelegend
370404: Tarmogoyf.text_parsed:
LANDARTIFACTINSTANTCREATURESORCERY!

Better picture than the original and one of the best flavor texts in the game. Shame these are so expensive even after the reprint. It's a potent creature, comparable to, ironically I might say, Scavenging Ooze yet more splashable. I just wish they weren't so darn expensive, since I like blue and I want to play modern.

On another note, seems like modern marginal cost/benefit analysis curves become rather steep with cards like these, since it's a card that is really just made to be thrown out there as a beat, and not the absolute tank that the price would imply ("dies to" argument). The question is how much better does this make (x), not how good the card is alone.

370404: Tarmogoyf.author: RobotOwl
370404: Tarmogoyf.text_parsed:
I am going to assume that all the people saying that this is the best creature in the game are only talking about Modern, because he is definitely not the best creature in Legacy right now. Although, he was for a long time.

The three best creatures in Legacy right now are (1) Stoneforge Mystic, (2) Deatrite Shaman, and (3) True-Name Nemesis. The Legacy format requires creatures to have insane utility, or for the Nemesis's case, to be an annoyingly unstoppable force / immovable object. Not just a cheap big guy.

Of course, I am not saying that Tarmogoyf is not a powerful card. Like infernox10 said, "for just 1G, you get a card that gets better by just playing Magic: The Gathering." Automatic synergy with any aggro strategy. And like I already mentioned, he was the best creature for a long time. It is definitely still top 5 and only because Delver of Secrets gets 4th for being able to fly over Nemesis.

370405: Progenitus.author: DarthParallax
370405: Progenitus.text_parsed:
I’m sorry, but I don’t want to be an Emperor – that’s not my business. I don’t want to rule or conquer anyone. I should like to help everyone, if possible — Jew, gentile, black man, white. We all want to help one another; human beings are like that. We want to live by each other’s happiness, not by each other’s misery. We don’t want to hate and despise one another. In this world there’s room for everyone and the good earth is rich and can provide for everyone.

The way of life can be free and beautiful.

But we have lost the way.

Greed has poisoned men’s souls, has barricaded the world with hate, has goose-stepped us into misery and bloodshed. We have developed speed but we have shut ourselves in. Machinery that gives abundance has left us in want. Our knowledge has made us cynical, our cleverness hard and unkind. We think too much and feel too little. More than machinery, we need humanity. More than cleverness, we need kindness and gentleness. Without these qualities, life will be violent and all will be lost.

The aeroplane and the radio have brought us closer together. The very nature of these inventions cries out for the goodness in men, cries out for universal brotherhood for the unity of us all. Even now my voice is reaching millions throughout the world, millions of despairing men, women, and little children, victims of a system that makes men torture and imprison innocent people.

To those who can hear me I say, “Do not despair.” The misery that is now upon us is but the passing of greed, the bitterness of men who fear the way of human progress. The hate of men will pass and dictators die; and the power they took from the people will return to the people and so long as men die, liberty will never perish.

Soldiers: Don’t give yourselves to brutes, men who despise you, enslave you, who regiment your lives, tell you what to do, what to think and what to feel; who drill you, diet you, treat you like cattle, use you as cannon fodder. Don’t give yourselves to these unnatural men, machine men, with machine minds and machine hearts! You are not machines! You are not cattle! You are men! You have the love of humanity in your hearts. You don’t hate; only the unloved hate, the unloved and the unnatural.

Soldiers: Don’t fight for slavery! Fight for liberty! In the seventeenth chapter of Saint Luke it is written, “the kingdom of God is within man” — not one man, nor a group of men, but in all men, in you, you the people have the power, the power to create machines, the power to create happiness. You the people have the power to make this life free and beautiful, to make this life a wonderful adventure.

Then, in the name of democracy, let us use that power! Let us all unite!! Let us fight for a new world, a decent world that will give men a chance to work, that will give you the future and old age a security. By the promise of these things, brutes have risen to power, but they lie! They do not fulfill their promise; they never will. Dictators free themselves, but they enslave the people!! Now, let us fight to fulfill that promise!! Let us fight to free the world, to do away with national barriers, to do away with greed, with hate and intolerance. Let us fight for a world of reason, a world where science and progress will lead to all men’s happiness.

Soldiers: In the name of democracy, let us all unite!!!
--Charlie Chaplin




EDIT: I took off the (i) tags. Sorry about that peeps! Thanks @ senken- I didn't used to know where the random pages of italics came from. I'll be more careful about tagging a whole text-wall next time. :3 I like this speech though and think it would be funny to come out of Progenitus' mouth! XD

370405: Progenitus.author: GrimjawxRULES
370405: Progenitus.text_parsed:
@spiney: Mother of all creatures? What happened to good old Krosan Cloudscraper or Autochthon Wurm? Also with the extremely limited print run of Modern Masters combined with the hoarding habits of stores who got the product and the secondary market, the amount of extra copies in circulation will be quite minimal. The price of a Modern Master display has more than doubled, being sold for upwards of 400 $ or more outside of the US with people not opening their boxes because they know the price is going to rise.

I don't get why they would want to limit the print run so much anyway. Sure, some of the cards in modern are worth a fortune, but none of them are on the reserved list, and if Wizards really wanted Modern Masters to be an opportunity for people to get into the modern tournament scene, they should focus on lowering the cost of doing so instead of aiming to make Modern the next Legacy/Vintage where you can only compete if your wallet is fat enough.

370405: Progenitus.author: cranial.distraction

@RetroGaner3 @spiney

"And you think that modern masters was made solely for drafts? No it wasn't, it was Wizard's way of getting certain modern cards into circulation so that there's for more for new players to get."

Besides, Modern Masters has Sunburst and Domain cards. There are three land fetchers at common (Search for Tomorrow, Kodama's Reach, Terramorphic Expanse) and Vivid lands at uncommon. Not to mention a ton of card draw (Mulldrifter, Masked Admirers, Nantuko Shaman, Perlious Research, Petals of Insight, Thirst for Knowledge).

You laugh until your opponent casts Tromp the Domains and rolls over you with 10/10 Arcbound Wanderers and Skyreach Mantas, after your board state has been whittled away by Drag Down and Tribal Flames.

Progenitus is a perfect fit for that deck and is just icing on the five-color cake.

370405: Progenitus.author: ScytheWrath
370405: Progenitus.text_parsed:
You guys are all talking about how Final Judgement can and can't exile Progenitus, but what you don't understand is that O-Kagachi (the creature in the art from Final Judgement) IS Progenitus!
The flavor text from Progenitus is "The Soul of the World has returned," and some info on O-Kagachi taken from the MTG Salvation Wiki states that, "It was the soul of the world, the very first kami, as old as the plane itself."
It also says at the end of O-Kagachi's story that he was eventually defeated, and so that would explain how he has returned - even if he returned in a different plane, in a different form.
Is it not absolutely amazing that WOTC made this connection between planes, over (about) 5 years, and no one noticed?!?! Progenitus is just Final Judgement in creature form!!!

If this was common knowledge, could someone please inform me? This just blew my mind, especially figuring it out myself.
370405: Progenitus.text_posted:
You guys are all talking about how [autocard]Final Judgement[/autocard] can and can't exile [autocard]Progenitus[/autocard], but what you don't understand is that O-Kagachi (the creature in the art from [autocard]Final Judgement[/autocard]) [i]IS[/i] [autocard]Progenitus[/autocard]!
The flavor text from [autocard]Progenitus[/autocard] is [i]"The Soul of the World has returned,"[/i] and some info on O-Kagachi taken from the MTG Salvation Wiki states that,[i] "It was [u]the soul of the world[/u], the very first kami, as old as the plane itself."[/i]
It also says at the end of O-Kagachi's story that he was eventually defeated, and so that would explain how he has returned - even if he returned in a different plane, in a different form.
Is it not absolutely amazing that WOTC made this connection between planes, over (about) 5 years, and no one noticed?!?!  [autocard]Progenitus[/autocard] is just [autocard]Final Judgement[/autocard] in creature form!!!

If this was common knowledge, could someone please inform me?  This just blew my mind, especially figuring it out myself.

370405: Progenitus.author: Continue
370405: Progenitus.text_parsed:
Using the "DEBT" acronym, protection from everything means:

D - Progenitus can't be damaged. (On a card, this would be phrased "prevent all damage...".)
E - Progenitus can't be enchanted or equipped. (Or fortified, but that rarely matters.)
B - Progenitus can't be blocked.
T - Progenitus can't be targeted by spells or abilities. (shroud)
370405: Progenitus.text_posted:
Using the "DEBT" acronym, protection from everything means:

D - Progenitus can't be [i]damaged[/i]. (On a card, this would be phrased "prevent all damage...".)
E - Progenitus can't be [i]enchanted[/i] or [i]equipped[/i]. (Or fortified, but that rarely matters.)
B - Progenitus can't be [i]blocked[/i].
T - Progenitus can't be [i]targeted[/i] by spells or abilities. (shroud)

370408: Path to Exile.author: Zylo-
370408: Path to Exile.text_parsed:
This is one of those card that can help or hurt you..... Mana ramping your opponent even once can end your game quickly.. Play this twice on the wrong creatures and you can be in serious trouble fast as they cast bigger spells or more per turn...

There are many options for instant removal... Everyone compares this to Condemn.. situationally, condemn is the better spell IF they are attacking... Situational... Often over looked is Dismember... Instant removal you can cast for 1... Same as path.. And instead of mana ramping them, you just lose 4 life... Often times, you will have the three mana open on their turn and can resolve it with no negatives... Any big creatures with toughness greater than 5 are probably attacking and can be condemned... Or chump blocked by a smaller creature and also dismembered.

370411: Chalice of the Void.author: FireryIsland
370411: Chalice of the Void.text_parsed:
@ EdgarPoeAllen, A chalice set for x=2 will counter the chalice you try to cast for x=1, its CMC is Zero anywhere else but on the stack, unless you want x=0

202.3b When calculating the converted mana cost of an object with an {X} in its mana cost, X is treated as 0 while the object is not on the stack, and X is treated as the number chosen for it while the object is on the stack.
370411: Chalice of the Void.text_posted:

The number of decks that this absolutely fries in Legacy is staggering.
-Delver variants
-Storm
-burn
-zombardment
-belcher
-oops
-others..

Helps against:
-Manaless Dredge
-Affinity
-painter grindstone
-almost everything else..

370413: Dark Confidant.author: Nikeyeia
370413: Dark Confidant.text_parsed:
This card brings so much value.

Each card you draw should give more value than the amount of life you lost for it was worth. Remember, life is only a resource, and the amount doesn't matter as long as you're alive at the end. Tackle it onto a 2/1 creature that can be an aggressive beater or trade for other relevant cards while still granting card advantage, and you got yourself one hell of a card.

Worst case scenario, he eats removal for your win condition. A truly black card, both in flavor and mechanics.

5/5

370413: Dark Confidant.author: DarthParallax
370413: Dark Confidant.text_parsed:
TomTomat: Spend $5 on a Necropotence before you touch this. Don't bother trying to 'break' it, just play it like a 'REALLY' souped up Enchantment-version of Divination. Then build some decks with it. Lose a lot with those decks. Then give those decks to your opponents to play against you. Then lose a lot to decks with Necropotence in them.

I can see you know THAT Necropotence is good already. What you don't know, what I admit freely I don't know either, is HOW to play Necropotence. It's a skill-testing card to play with, actually. As many times as it can give you a 'free win', it can give that 'free win' to your opponents until you know what you're doing. Watch it work a bit. Let yourself get beat up by your own weapons so you can learn how to USE your weapons.

Then go back and compare the textboxes and typelines of Necropotence and Doctor Horrible here. (He needs a new name as it's no longer Bob. Doctor Doom felt cliché and Skrillex was what everyone else was saying).

This is a Necropotence THAT ATTACKS. and BLOCKS. Yes, the P/T is low. Yes, compared to SKULL, the card draw is slow and seemingly even more painful. But it combines Card Advantage with the Philosophy of Fire. Which is kind of like combining the Philosophy of Oil with the Philosophy of Fire.

It Draws Cards.
And it Attacks.
And it Blocks.
And it Costs only 2 Mana.

Go ahead and play it in your Kaalia of the Vast Commander decks. It is much more splashable than Necropotence, which is of huge relevance because you'll be shooting from the hip on mana, intending to cheat practically all colors and costs. If you figure out how to do it right (which would include a couple cards devoted to Huge Gobs of Lifegain), then even topdecking a Draco that you intend to put into play tapped and attacking for free ought to be something your deck is not afraid of doing.

Congregate + Dark Confidant is fair to call a "combo" in KaaliaEDH. :)

@Everyone on Gatherer: Buy Necropotence and use it to learn how to play MAGIC. Proxy Dark Confidant and use it to learn how to play MAGIC with Non-Vintage, Tournament Legal Cards.

370413: Dark Confidant.author: Ferlord
370413: Dark Confidant.text_parsed:
There's always that moment in a young Magic player's mind when they become more than a beginner. It's the moment when you realize the "Greatness" rather than the "Cost".

If anyone pays attention to my previous comments, they'll know I only play EDH and Limited. They're not the best formats for understanding the "Greatness", since you've never seen it in action.

So when I first heard of this card, I thought it was nothing special. "Ok... what's wrong with Dark Tutelage? Why isn't that $10 or so?". It's the usual thinking most players start with. Losing life is a big thing, especially when you rationalize that you could lose 12 life drawing a Blightsteel Colossus (the Boogeyman of Magic: everyone's heard of him and fears him).

But then it clicked, like it clicks for everyone eventually. "You don't play it with anything more than 3-cost. You get an attacker/blocker and a card, all for ."

So for those who are giving those who don't think this is a good card a hard time, put yourself in their shoes. If you main-decked cards like Goblin Game and Decree of Pain, would you think this is good?

Then why not run Demonic Tutor over this? Same mana curve, gives you exactly the card you want, thirty dollars cheaper at least.

Yet Sovereign is more sought after. people say it's the 2/1 for two creature that gives it it's edge, and I'm willing to bet that that's the reason why people think Dark Confidant is better than dark tutelage.

What I don't get is that 2/1's can be knocked out by pretty much every known type of creature removal, which is almost always rampant in all decks. The price difference between this and tutelage is grossly more vast though and it perplexes me.

370413: Dark Confidant.author: EvilDarkVoid
370413: Dark Confidant.text_parsed:
@SerGarlan: Demonic Tutor is banned in Legacy and hasn't been printed recently enough to be in Modern (don't think for a second it wouldn't be banned there if it was, though) and is Restricted in Vintage. Its hardly fair to say Dark Confidant is bad because of how it matches up to a card you're not even allowed to play...

Demonic Tutor is also a totally different type of card. It gives you one card of your choice, right now, which is most useful for combo decks (although it costs so little that non-combo decks would love to use it too). Dark Confidant gives you consistent card advantage turn after turn. If it survives even a turn its gotten you a card back, so you've still got card advantage when he gets removed. Even if he gets killed before your first upkeep, he's still only 2 cost, so it probably took your opponent's entire turn as well, meaning that you haven't really lost tempo or card advantage.

Say an opponent doesn't kill Dark Confidant (maybe they don't run removal, or just didn't draw into it, whatever) and now you've got lots of card advantage. Assuming the rest of your deck is built well, you're almost certainly going to win when you're seeing double as many cards (and therefore double as many options) as your opponent.

And, finally, you seriously underestimate the advantages of being a creature as well. While Dark Confidant does die to removal, that can actually save you the game! Say you're in control of a game, your opponent can't stick a threat, but your life total has gotten dangerously low. A Dark Confidant trigger or two has a chance of killing you. No problem! Just throw a Lightning Bolt, Swords to Plowshares, etc. at it, and you're in the clear, whereas having Dark Tutelage or Phyrexian Arena might kill you. Its much too risky to run mainboard Erases or even Naturalizes for those situations, as many decks don't use Enchantments or Artifacts (Bolt is even moderately useful against creatureless decks too, and Path/Swords can be used on your own creatures in a pinch).

Plus, as a creature, he can chump-block to save you once the game is coming to a close. Say you're at a low life total and an opponent's Tarmogoyf is going to finish you off soon. The Arena or Tutelege aren't going to prevent any of that damage-they'll just add to it. But with the Confidant, you can block the 'Goyf (or other non-evasive threat) and conveniently lose his own threat to your life total as well. He can also kill your opponent (or at least put some damage on them) as he's helping you draw removal for their would-be blockers.

This isn't to say that Phyrexian Arena or Dark Tutelage are bad cards. The Arena is a lot better if you'e running high cost cards in your deck (not likely in Modern or Legacy though) and Tutelage is basically a balanced (read: weaker) version of them.

370413: Dark Confidant.author: Aquillion
370413: Dark Confidant.text_parsed:
Shouldn't he be an adviser?

@Paleopaladin: Also, the fact that he's a creature is a big deal. In the card advantage decks based around him, you will generally be running a bunch of cheap high-power creatures and a bunch of cheap removal, with the goal of trading removal one-for-one with your opponent's blockers and threats, while swarming them with your creatures before they can put together anything more complicated or dangerous.

If you put four Phyrexian Arenas or Dark Tutelages in a deck, you lose a bit of pressure on your opponent when you spend the card and mana to play one, and then you run the risk of losing even more if you draw another one as your extra card (which is not as good as it sounds because your whole deck depends on keeping up the pressure right now rather than a few turns from now.) Whereas if your Dark Confidant draws you another Dark Confidant, you can play it and use it as another beatstick to end the game more quickly.

370414: Kataki, War's Wage.author: DarthParallax
370414: Kataki, War's Wage.text_parsed:
Check out Tabernacle of Pendrell Vale. In THEORY Atali is SUPPOSED to be right. That was the intent.

My understanding of the general consensus says that if MAGIC were good, then this card would matter a lot more. As far as Standard goes, no, this card never mattered and Affinity was Sillier than Seuss. XD
As far as Extended goes, I believe it was the same story.

I think older, fouler things than Arcbound Ravager have always ruled Legacy and Vintage, but I could be wrong. For interesting context, could anyone post what Legacy looked like roughly when Kataki was Standard-legal?

However, Modern is just the format for Kataki to shine in. He will keep Arcbound Ravager from getting banned. He, um, makes no promises that you'll actually win if you play him though. You want to build the whole shebang with Knight of the Reliquary and Tarmogoyf if you want want him to do that much for you XD

TL;DR: You NEED to own this guy. But Arcbound Ravager is WAY better than this guy. Because sometimes WOTC takes cocaine during Development. :S

370415: Ivory Giant.author: Ferlord
370415: Ivory Giant.text_parsed:
This is one hell of a dangerous common. I noticed that a bunch of commons were turned into uncommons (like Horobi's Whisper), probably to hose down the amount of them found in a draft.

That begs the question: Why wasn't this uncommon?

The effect is quite grand, and can sometimes be as one-sided as Sleep. This can sometimes be better than Sleep since it can cost just , White doesn't have as many means to tap down creatures as Blue does (but there's still a lot of White tappers), and you also get a creature.

Amazing high-pick in limited, watch out for the hard-cast: it could win you the game.

370419: Blood Moon.author: MrFluffyThing
370419: Blood Moon.text_parsed:
@chainsmoker

Blood Moon changes the way non-basic lands exist ON the battlefield, but do not change the way they enter the battlefield. Because checklands, shock lands, and gates are not effected by continuous effects on the battlefield while the land is being played, it will hit the board tapped (Or with the Pay-2-life replacement effect). See: Rule 614.12

370419: Blood Moon.author: DarthParallax
370419: Blood Moon.text_parsed:
I expect this is the first card in this set (alphabetically) to strongly affect the secondary market in a mostly irreversible way.

Now we have a lot more black-bordered Foils of Blood Moon, AND a LOT more Black Borders of it in general. This is not something that is very relevant for most of the cards in this set. This card is only Modern Legal because of a white-bordered Core Set printing. And it's a Rare. A Good Rare.

That...changes things. For the better, I'm sure. :)

Secondly, this is Glowing Red, the other Moon was very Rocky. 370419: Blood Moon.author: blurrymadness
370419: Blood Moon.text_parsed:
There are a variety of decks in Legacy that spam Moon effects but become quite unreliable due to the acceleration involved. That said, I quite like the idea posted to put it into a Goblin deck. I'd have to try it out but they not only like accel (which could be used instead of Lackey) but they get a lot of natural card advantage.

Goblins tend to be good at beating other mono-color decks either because they're blue (Piledriver) or because of nasty kill cards like Incinerator while getting actual card advantage unlike D&T.

370419: Blood Moon.author: absreim
370419: Blood Moon.text_parsed: My favorite card in Magic. The existence of this card has a very positive effect on the metagame in the eternal formats because it makes deckbuilders have to balance the inclusion of basic and non-basic lands in the mana base. Otherwise, there wouldn't be as much incentive to play one or two-colored decks with all the mana-fixing available in those formats.

370419: Blood Moon.author: OlvynChuru
370419: Blood Moon.text_parsed: When I first saw this card, I didn't realize that it got rid of the abilities of the lands. That function of Blood Moon is REALLY unintuitive. 370419: Blood Moon.author: RyugenS
370419: Blood Moon.text_parsed:
@OlvynChuru The key phrase that differentiates Dralnu's Crusade from this is the "in addition to its other types" phrase. If Blood Moon also had a similar phrase, it would've let nonbasic lands keep their original types. As is, it literally turns all nonbasic lands into mountains.
See Urborg, Tomb of Yawgmoth for an effect closer to what you were expecting.
370419: Blood Moon.text_posted:
@OlvynChuru The key phrase that differentiates [autocard]Dralnu's Crusade[/autocard] from this is the "in addition to its other types" phrase. 370425: Glimmervoid.author: DarthParallax
370425: Glimmervoid.text_parsed:
Mutavault would have been pretty gay for draft -_- It would have made the changelings too good, and all the different Tribal cards would get fought over too much by both the players of the Real tribes and the Changelings players.

This is an honestly nice card to see because if you try to go artifacts, or if some dummy passes you Arcbound Ravager and you find yourself IN Artifacts, but you also are pretty sure your deck is going to be running a good amount of color, this card can help you be a 'half artifacts, half X' deck.

It's not something you deliberately go for, it's something your draft pool could force you into. There's a number of cards that are cross-synergetic with lots of things in the set that serve basically this function. :)

Also, if you just like City of Brass, here's another City of Brass. :P Actually that's really a good reason too: They didn't have this card in Scars of Mirrodin, but Commander and all the other, many, varied target audiences Modern Masters is trying to reach...they all want a few more copies of both City of Brass and Glimmervoid out there to buy. They're no Command Tower...but they're cheaper than Fetch Lands, and you can run all 3. :)

370427: Eternal Witness.author: Mode
370427: Eternal Witness.text_parsed:
"Sweet card in EDH."
@tut07 This is a sweet cards in many formats :D

I like the fact that Wizards went for the exact same flavor text and artwork in every printing of this card so far.
And rightly so, i just adore Terese Nielsen's art.
It's immediately recognizable, and the atmosphere just feels right for this card: The calmness, the isolation, her idle yet attentive pose, the beams of light breaking through the unseen canopy, probably alluding to the original Regrowth.
Brilliant.

Plus, you still have a rather unotrusive details that reminds us that she's in The Tangle of Mirrodin:
Not her entire outfit is made of ivy; those are actually green-colored metal plates on her shoulders. And most notably, the blue metal on her front is probably part of her body, a trademark exclusive for folks of that metal plane.

370427: Eternal Witness.author: JaxsonBateman
370427: Eternal Witness.text_parsed:
So good in so many decks. Personally, I'm a UG and WG fan. In UG, it gets lots of those control cards back out that you just love. In particular, if you're running Counterspell/Cryptic Command it proves solid there, and can also give you an instant-speed powerful mana dump if you're running a deck with Cackling Counterpart.

In WG, I love Sun Titan's oft-powerful recursion, and given that E-Wit is 3 mana she's an eligible target. So Sun Titan more or less reads "put a 3 CMC permanent on the battlefield, or any other card into your hand". Great for instants like Swords to Plowshares, or sorceries like Wrath of God. Works best with some way to sacrifice her to force the effect, but totally fine without a sac outlet - if they want to attack into you on the ground, they'll be offering you a way to get her into the graveyard.

370428: Street Wraith.author: HotHit
370428: Street Wraith.text_parsed:
Possibly an alright sideboard card, but unless you're in black or playing a graveyard focused strategy (which probably also means you're in black), you have no reason to take this. Maybe if you can really take advantage of having street wraith's cycling it's worthy of being main deck, such as dredge decks where it can set off a dredge for 2 life.

I value deck thinning and especially creatures that act as spells for Domri Rade to find. Krosan Tusker, which has a similar ability and can work with the same tactics, is currently one of my favourite cards right now. But unfortunately, I don't see the power of an opening of 4 street wraiths in my grave, 2 land and a low mana dude in hand, 4 cards that I don't know what they're gonna be and 12 life.

370428: Street Wraith.author: Mode

"Enables 36- or fewer card decks in Limited. 44-card decks in Constructed with this, Mishra's Bauble, Urza's Bauble, and Gitaxian Probe. Pretty good for Legacy Dredge. Awesome reprint."

@SyntheticDreamer I do not remember any limited Format that offered all four of these cards; or even two of them :P

Edit (since 6/11/13):
"@Mode: There's a key word you skipped over. ;)"
Whoops, i realized my comment doesn't really make sense either way - for some reason i was thinking 36 because you'd draft exactly one copy of each mentioned card :D

But as SAUS33 pointed out, you'll get to thin your deck out by as many cards as you happen to draft Street Wraiths - simple as that. It's not like you 'unlock' up to four copies of them for each one you draft, haha.
There's no four-copy-rule whatsoever, therefore talking about "36 or less" was misleading.
Also keep in mind it's basically impossible to stitch together a combo-based deck in limited,
so the idea of thinning your deck out seems pointless either way ;)

370428: Street Wraith.author: Dr.Pingas
370428: Street Wraith.text_parsed:
Not a fan
Real mathmatic application will show the amount of deck thinning this guy provides nets you more effort required than average measurable reward per game.

The worst part is its not even good. Could be a 0/1 for 7cmc and nobody would care, its overall functionality would be uneffected - you want the cycle, and maybe to cheat it out later by reanimation, if at all. A 3/4 swampwalk for 5? Eww.

Given the average number of cards you need to thin per turn to make a relevant, significant, and consistent difference - much less one that can be legitimately considered advantageous - Cards like this that function soley for the purpose of lowering virtual deck count end up making the deck worse off than a card that provides real advantage or strategic value

Is brutal with Flicker effects, is solid as a rock as a finisher and decent as a bounce spell. can be mained as a 4-of if you're careful, which is what Evoke creatures do best: They're a play on multiple turns allowing you to smooth out your curve more reliably and their ETB effects are mega-abusable.

Seriously finishes games for me reliably.

370432: Tooth and Nail.author: brunsbr103
370432: Tooth and Nail.text_parsed:
Now hold the phone, this card is good. It is rip-roaring foe-splathering devastating-to-your-opponent good. Do you like creatures? Tooth and Nail has got you COVERED. Do you like casting spells? Tooth and Nail IS one. Do you like tutors? Good.

Now I haven't even gotten to the good part about this card. Let me tell you about these options. Options like tutoring up a Mystic Snake and a Sylvan Primordal from your deck, then putting that Primordal RIGHT ONTO THE FIELD along with that Avenger of Zendikar that you've had in your hand for a few turns. Options like slapping that Craterhoof Behemoth AND that Hornet Queen right into play on turn 6 FOR THE WIN.

Drew the card you wanted to tutor up with it? NO PROBLEM put it right on the field along with something else. Need an answer to pretty much anything? NO PROBLEM just make sure you have answers in your deck and BOOM your problems are gone.

Not playing green?

Well why not.

Tooth and Nail.

370434: Frogmite.author: DarthParallax
370434: Frogmite.text_parsed:
I always, and still, think Frogmite is slightly stupid flavorwise. It's...a frog? is that Necrogen or Blinkmoth infusion inside it? It looks frosty? It's a FROG artifact? :P Really? :P

But Good Lord, I just can't argue with Results O.O I downright wouldn't play this guy when I was a new Magic player and flavor and Timmy was all that mattered. But that has Changed. I really want to play a deck with Arcbound Ravager in it. I understand that that deck will need to play four of these. I don't entirely look forward to casting the little Frogmite, I still wish they had made an "Arcbound" creature with the Affinity ability. It would have been cool.

But I will greatly enjoy building and bashing with one of the greatest Decks in all of MAGIC. None of the good Onslaught or Odyssey or Invasion decks actually made people quit. Affinity, Caw-Blade, and Urza's Block share a distinguished position in MTG History:

Even the other Stupid Decks Hate how Stupid they are! ^_^ I believe the product "Archenemy" was first made possible after the SECOND Great Screw Up of R&D: Affinity. Now, in the post Third Great Screw Up world (Jace/Caw Blade), we actually have a portion of our players who like it when WOTC Screws Up. We like it when we can build Archenemy Decks to machine gun the crap out of our friends.

I wonder what the Fourth Great Screw Up will be? :)

370436: Myr Enforcer.author: Mode
370436: Myr Enforcer.text_parsed:
I also prefer the original artwork.
Jim Murray's take on Myr Enforcer looks more like something Phyrexian because of those arms made up of muscles and sinews, but not to an entirely artificial being like the Myr it is.

Then again, even the original artwork itself was the biggest exception from your average Myr anatomy in comparison to the other Myr that existed back then; since it doesn't have that prominent beak-like head.
But it wasn't the only one, though.
Therefore i thought there were two major Myr species, 'minors' like Mana Myr and 'overseers' like Myr Enforcer and Lodestone Myr. But that concept was either wrong or has been discontinued in Return to Mirrodin, since Myr Superion's head uses the common/'minor' appearance. The body itself is bold and has broad appendages though, so there might be something to it after all.

370438: Feudkiller's Verdict.author: SAUS3
370438: Feudkiller's Verdict.text_parsed:
Life gain is overall bad when it is what you are paying for. This card is like a 5/5 for 6 with ETB gain 10 life (a lot of the time anyway). Life gain alone is bad (heroes' reunion), but when you get it tacked onto other things, it can really help.

A lot of times, when you need life gain, it's because your opponent is playing very aggressively. Usually they play in such a way that makes them slowly lose cards, but for the purpose of reducing your life total to the point where you have to make bad trades (chumps or overkill with removal) in order to stay alive. If you gain some life, you essentially made your opponent waste their cards.

370439: Cryptic Command.author: Hepatizon
370439: Cryptic Command.text_parsed:
I happen to love that there's the occasional incentive to monocolor. As others have pointed out, this is the chief of medium-cost blue spells.

Despite the "expense", it's so horribly versatile. It can bounce resurrected monsters, stop hoards of unblockable and hexproof monsters in their tracks, counter spells and on-tap abilities and give card advantage and trigger on-draw effects all at instant speed.

As if I wasn't already automatically suspicious whenever anyone kept that much blue mana untapped at their end step.

370439: Cryptic Command.author: Saikuba
370439: Cryptic Command.text_parsed:
Usually modal spells are a bit overcosted for what they actually do. They are usable because of the added flexibility that they give you. For example Assault // Battery gives you a sorcery shock or a green hill giant. Neither option is great on its own but the choice to vary between removal or threat makes it playable.

Here any combination of the two abilities is already worth four mana. When you consider that there are six different possibilities for its casting mode, all of which are on curve, the flexibility that this gives you is insane.

The fact that in Modern three color decks often run four copies of this card despite how difficult it is to cast is a testament to just how powerful it is.

It is one of the reasons that controlling decks manage to remain competitive at all in Modern, a format dominated by midrange and combo and where Lightning Bolt is the most-played card.

370439: Cryptic Command.author: JaxsonBateman
370439: Cryptic Command.text_parsed:
Totally brilliant, as most people know. Four entirely useful modes, at instant speed, for a fair cost. While UUU makes it sometimes-awkward in decks, in 2 color decks it oft isn't a problem, and is worth the value.

Personally, I love UG, and Cryptic Command is totally at home alongside Eternal Witness. And if you get up to 7 mana - which is totally doable with green's early ramp, as you'll often start with a turn 1 Noble Hierarch - then you can set up a vice-grip on your opponent's combat abilities, by choosing tap + bounce targetting your own E-Wit. Of course, removal can mess with that plan, but the fact is that you're forcing them to burn removal on a 3 mana 2/1, and simply because of a synergy between two cards which are perfectly fine on their own.

And of course, with blue's dig you'll probably find another E-Wit... >:-3

370442: Bonesplitter.author: Taudisban
370442: Bonesplitter.text_parsed:
Fun fact: White (the equipment loving color) and green (the creature loving color) are the only colors that can't beat for 5 turn two with a Bonesplittered creature. Red and Blue can do it evasively and without losing card advantage.

Blue has Delver of Secrets (flipped) and NivMagus Elemental (with a free spell) and Blistercoil Weird (with two free spells), which it shares with red. Red also has Goblin Gaveleer. Black has Kjeldoran Dead (with a 0-drop creature) and Circling Vultures (with an extra copy to discard).

Edit: Sorry white, forgot about Kor Duelist.

370442: Bonesplitter.author: blurrymadness
370442: Bonesplitter.text_parsed:
In a lot of ways this is a rebalanced Rancor:
-+2/+0 for 1, +1 equip. (Typically equipments are double the cost of their enchant companions after factoring the equip cost)
-No trample; because cheap trample granting things that also pump power make any tiny creature a huge source of continual damage
-Can be destroyed!

But nothing is stopping you from running them next eachother and having a 5/1 Scryb Sprite. Also, this is a beautiful fetch target for Trinket Mage IMO. His trinket is a giant axe :D.

370442: Bonesplitter.author: Antsache
370442: Bonesplitter.text_parsed:
@ Blurrymadness

In some environments this can be even more resilient than Rancor, since instant-speed bounce/kill on Rancor's target while the enchantment is on the stack is a common way to destroy it for good. (Not like you can afford to wait three turns to dodge a lightning bolt when you're playing aggro) Equipment generally doesn't die to creature removal, though - you'll just end up wasting an equip cost. Not to mention Tormod's Crypt and other instant-speed sideboard graveyard hate.

The addition of trample and the lower CMC for getting it out for the first time still usually make Rancor a significantly more powerful card in green decks, of course. Bonesplitter definitely feels more balanced as a result, while still being plenty powerful.


@ Sabisent

He never said that making any of those plays was a good idea. He was just noting a very obscure, contrived bit of trivia. The fact that it turned out to be wrong (in White's case) makes it even less notable.

Also, though it seems he's not counting anything that requires delving into a second/third color, Wild Nacatl probably at least deserves consideration for green, as the card itself is in-color... it just relies on dropping a Plateau turn two to hit 5 with the 'splitter.

If you're drafting green in MM, do yourself a favor and pick these up.

370449: Flickerwisp.author: Havrekjex
370449: Flickerwisp.text_parsed:
The first time I saw this card, I saw a poor man's Restoration Angel. I thought that it was hopelessly inferior because it doesn't have flash, and the exiled permanent doesn't return until EOT. Then it dawned on me... any permanent. While it isn't as effective as Resto and Cloudshift for abusing your own ETB triggers, and it can't save a creature mid-combat, it has about a million other applications. This is based on someone else's work, props to the guy who wrote this on a certain Internet forum.

1. Cast it to reuse a positive ETB trigger on one of your creatures (Thragtusk, Blade Splicer), or a negative one on one of your opponent's creatures (Phyrexian Dreadnought).
2. Cast it to untap one of your own creatures after attacking with it.
3. Cast it targeting your own land to untap it, basically making it cost one less mana that you can use on something at instant speed (Path to Exile and Lighting Bolt ready in your opponent's turn).
4. Cast it to remove a blocker.
5. Cast it to kill one of your opponent's creature tokens.
6. Cast it to remove/reset counters;
__a) targeting an opposing Æther Vial, Engineered Explosives, Chalice of the Void, Protean Hydra, etc. to remove all counters from it.
__b) targeting a planeswalker to reset its number of loyalty counters.
__c) targeting your own permanent to remove upkeep counters (Jötun Grunt), vanishing counters (Deadwood Treefolk), fading counters, -1/-1 counters (Kitchen Finks), +1/+1 counters (Geralf's Messenger).
__d) targeting your own permanent to restore counters (Triskelion, Serrated Arrows).
7. Cast it targeting your Oblivion Ring or Phyrexian Revoker to switch targets when it comes back.
8. Cast it targeting another Flickerwisp you own so that when the second comes back, it removes something for the entire next turn.

For many of the cards mentioned as examples, there are literally hundreds of others with similar functions. Yet, all this is just the tip of the iceberg compared to what you can do with it if you've also got Æther Vial. Instant speed breaks this card in half.

Probably one of my favourite cards ever. 5/5.

370453: Take Possession.author: Atali
370453: Take Possession.text_parsed:
Split second and Instant speed are not the same thing, are not mutually exclusive, and are not really comparable. Split second simply can't be responded to, ensuring that the spell will resolve.
This is a very significant way to steal a planeswalker though. You gain priority after the stack empties and can activate a planeswalker ability before anyone has a chance to remove Take Posession or the 'walker. This lets you steal a 'walker ready to pop its ult and use it right away without your opponent having a chance to stop you; unless they're running Trickbind or Voidslime.

I'm surprised they haven't thought of printing this after the Time Spiral block.
It's arguable that this is better than Giant Growth just because of the colour you're in. Although, it's really hard to rationalize this since Red is almost as, if not more, aggressive than Green.

That being said, Red hasn't been as supportive of creatures as Green has. That means that to take fuller advantage of this (and make sure it's not a dead-draw), you need to be playing a bunch of creatures. If you are, this kind of does the same as a Lightning Bolt would.

Anyway, thanks WotC for printing this in this set.
