370455: Sword of Light and Shadow.author: DarthParallax
370455: Sword of Light and Shadow.text_parsed:
There are two Swords that give Protection from Black.
Sword of Feast and Famine gives wildly more powerful triggered abilities than most of the rest of them- it gives direct card and mana advantage, very simple and plain to see, and feels almost as cheaty as Tinker.
But "Flying" is very nearly "Protection from Green" (it IS "Protection from Green Creatures" for 99% of purposes. Sigarda being a Giant Jerk of an Exception).

There are two swords that give Protection from White.
Sword of War and Peace gives almost amazingly OP effects, except it really is just overall "Win More"- it swings life points a whole lot after you've already got the Card Advantages and Disadvantages swinging in the directions you want them to.

Wrath of God and Doom Blade will find knockoffs of themselves, in both Black and White, in every deck running either color. Protection from Red isn't as relevant as you might think, since the tempo disadvantage of casting and equipping a Sword early could be enough to win it for the Red Deck, and against a Red Deck there shouldn't really be a late game. In Duels. In Multiplayer or other Casual games of all sorts, you'll have to deal with the occasional Dragon or Bonfire, but really those cards are hard to justify running over Angels, Demons, and Better Stuff in Black and White.

The "Best Sword?" Debate could go on for almost as long as the "Best Color?" Debate and is highly dependent on format and metagame, but "Best Sword to Default to" is Sword of Light and Shadow, because White and Black have the most "Answer Target/All X" Default Spells.

EDIT: Yeah, it doesn't actually Stop Wraths, but it's good against the Colors of Decks where Wrath appears. That's still worth a lot. Sword of War and Peace and Sword of Light and Shadow are two of the best Swords because you get the most Mileage out of their Protections. Very well worth enchanting a Sworded creature to give it Flying.
Sword of Feast and Famine is the only Sword that I am truly in awe of it's abilities. Sword of Fire and Ice and Sword of Body and Mind feel like 'fair, strong abilities', but Feast and Famine feels bahroken.

370455: Sword of Light and Shadow.author: SAUS3
370455: Sword of Light and Shadow.text_parsed:
The art on this version is beautiful. I like the most visible thing in the picture is the light half of the sword.

@DarthParallax
Wrath of God actually will still kill the equipped creature. Protection does not stop 'destroy' effects from killing them and it only prevents things that 'target' the creature. It also prevents damage from sources that it has protection from so protection from red is definitely still very strong (as long as they are not super aggro - ie mono red).

I also want to point out that this is one of the weaker swords. The life gain is kind of weak, and returning the creature is conditional (you have to have a dead creature). However, I still love this card and if you have a deck that makes a lot of creatures dead, it can be really good card advantage (since each time it goes, you get to choose which creature you want).

EDIT
I think people overestimate how important the colours of the protection are. The point of equipment is that if the equipped creature is killed, you can just throw it on a new creature. It doesn't even have to be a big creature. That's particularly the case with the swords which have so many bonus effects.

EDIT2
Finally got it in the mail :D This is undoubtedly the prettiest sword. Looks so good.
The main thing the protections do for the swords, is make it so your creature can't get blocked. You'll find very quickly that if you have this sword against a blue/green deck, it won't be doing very much for you. That's no the case for sword of fire and ice against a white/black deck since it will still cause a lot of damage if it gets through.

370460: Otherworldly Journey.author: HotHit
370460: Otherworldly Journey.text_parsed:
A more powerful and more flexible cloudshift. Oh don't think so? There are niche cases where cloudshift is better (Aurelia, the Warleader can't give you a third combat step for example), but things otherworldly journey can do that cloudshift can't include:

+1/+1 counters.
Allow key creatures to dodge board sweepers.
Temporarily remove enemy threats to potentially crush them that turn.
Trade enchantments for a +1/+1 counter.
Makes undying creatures vulnerable.
Be an arcane spell.
Remove enemy tokens.
Release your creatures from being the puppets of blue or black mages.

Damn... The more I think about it the more I want a playset.

370460: Otherworldly Journey.author: jonrds
370460: Otherworldly Journey.text_parsed:
Now that damage doesnt go on the stack, I think Wizards should somehow try to bring that feature back in a new card. Maybe a r/w flicker with "deals damage equal to its power to another target creature" tacked on to the end. Or possibly a g/w card like "otherworldly fight" that exiles 2 creatures and returns the one with higher power.

Then there's graceful reprieve, grim return, undying evil, reincarnation, faith's reward, second sunrise, rescue from the underworld, antler skulkin, cauldron of souls, cauldron haze and even saffi eriksdotter for returning creature cards from the graveyard to play. Those are kindof like a blink with the combat stack still there.

Now that I think about it, undying evil is pretty much exactly otherworldly journey before the combat change (with a few changes, including needing a sac outlet and the oh so amazing change of triggering dying abilities).

370464: Pardic Dragon.author: TheZombifier
370464: Pardic Dragon.text_parsed:
"This sucks, 6cmc for a 4/4 that will probably never get on the battlefield"

You guys always only look at their mana costs and don't see how good card this can be.

At first, it has ONLY two mana suspend. You won't probably have anything amazing with two mana in your hand during your second turn.
At second, this freaks your opponent out. He/She thinks that he/she must play spell each turn or all will be lost. Not many think about this "mental gaming" when constructing their decks, even when it can easily harm your opponent's game.
At third, its like Volcanic Dragon without haste and with handful ability. And yet still some players play Volcanic Dragon. Volcanic Dragon doesn't even have suspend!

Useful and even lethal. 3.5/5 from me.

370464: Pardic Dragon.author: blurrymadness
370464: Pardic Dragon.text_parsed:
One possible way to get him out is Winter Orb:
T2 Winter Orb
T3 Land, Pardic Dragon :D
T4 Land, Sphere of Resistance (not necessary, but probably in the deck)

Also, in color Rift Elemental?! They add counters to him you get fatter beats out of your 1-drop!
T1 Rift Elemental
T2 Pardic
T3 Rip a counter off of him and trade favorably or hit for 3
T4 Rip two counters off of him and hit for up to 5. At this point you've removed 5 counters; he's probably attacking!

Another fun thing:
T1 Flailing Soldier or Branded Brawlers
T2 Pardic

Do they cast spells to keep your pardic down or do they spend mana on the soldier? Either way you get a fun oversized creature.

You just have to be more creative than "Dur, burn cards" with this guy.

370465: Fury Charm.author: auriscope
370465: Fury Charm.text_parsed:
I think people are severely undervaluing this card in r/g suspend. Dropping a hasty 5/5 on people 2 turns earlier than anticipated can put people in a very bad spot; obviously remove the last two counters with this, otherwise the element of surprise is lost. You can even pop creatures into play from suspend during combat.

...and that's only ONE mode, the pump/trample is nice for the beefy creatures that r/g attracts, particularly because most of them lack native trample. Being able to mainboard artifact removal is also nice, since you pretty much lose something like Sword of Fire and Ice if it lands and you aren't prepared to destroy it.
370465: Fury Charm.text_posted:

370469: Rift Bolt.author: rollinsclone
370469: Rift Bolt.text_parsed:
@S0larfall
The set that this was first released in, Time Spiral, was the 'nostalgia' set and had a lot of cards in it that were references to other cards that weren't strict reprints. This was their homage to Lightning Bolt. As for it compared to Bolt, for a long time Bolt was considered too powerful to reprint, that's why you have cards such as this and Shock, references to the best red card ever made without being as good or better. Also, there are advantages to suspending this, lorendorky says it pretty well in his comment. That being said, in a straight burn deck this is meant to be run alongside Bolt as another 3 damage for 1 mana spell.

On to the card, I much prefer this art to my Time Spiral ones and I'm looking forward to picking up some foil copies for my burn deck.

Loving the new art. Already ordered one even though I almost just got the old one. The new art is just too awesome to pass up.

I also want to point out how strong this card is. You get to clear out utility creatures or deal even more damage to the player. The extra card draw means that after 1 hit, even if they remove it next turn, it is a 2-for-1. This card is just really strong. It's also a good source of colourless draw.

If your opponent has a blue/red deck, if they can't dig out an answer, they likely get steamrolled.

370472: Grapeshot.author: Nucleon
370472: Grapeshot.text_parsed:
Art critique aside, and I do like the art...

I think players can be misled by this.

Storm decks are absurdly cheap, yes, but that's because they need the Manamorphose/Seething Song/Gitaxian Probe/etc. complete package. If you're lucky in draft or sealed, MAYBE you can get a storm count for4 on turn 5. I'm not saying Storm, one of the most broken mechanics ever, should have been better in MM, far from it. I'm just saying that it doesn't really work without all the support it needs, and at least Dredge got the Retrace cards to play with.

It's been made more fair, however, and I'd love to set up a burn deck with Grapeshot, but players who draft it should NOT expect the antics that, say, Affinity and Faeries are still capable of in-set. Storm is not nearly as powerful as constructed decks with it are, and that's a very good thing.
370472: Grapeshot.text_posted:
Art critique aside, and I do like the art...

I think players can be misled by this.

Storm decks are absurdly cheap, yes, but that's because they need the Manamorphose/Seething Song/Gitaxian Probe/etc. complete package. If you're lucky in draft or sealed, MAYBE you can get a storm count for4 on turn 5. I'm not saying Storm, one of the most broken mechanics ever, should have been better in MM, far from it. I'm just saying that it doesn't really work without all the support it needs, and at least Dredge got the Retrace cards to play with. 

It's been made more fair, however, and I'd love to set up a burn deck with Grapeshot, but players who draft it should NOT expect the antics that, say, Affinity and Faeries are still capable of in-set. Storm is not nearly as powerful as constructed decks with it are, and that's a very good thing.

370472: Grapeshot.author: cardraptor6
370472: Grapeshot.text_parsed:
As a relatively new player (started at New Phyrexia) one of the complaints I often make about older cards (besides weird color-pie stuff and walls of awkward text) is the fact that almost all of the old artwork was pretty crappy, and looked like the kind of van art you'd see on an old-school geek's ride. Now that I've seen the modern interpretation of the Grapeshot artwork, representing the kind of people they want to buy their cards lately, I'm not too thrilled. *sigh*

Though it is a nice case study in geek culture, if you're into that kind of thing. Look at the old and new art side by side and you can witness what kind of stereotypical geek fantasy stuff gets marketed to:

Old geek: Fat, sweaty, wearing a ripped black Star Wars t-shirt, with long, unwashed hair riding a van painted with a wizard fighting an eagle and rocking to Metallica while sloppily munching on Combos and Surge.
New geek: Socially awkward high school kid who likes to act smug and tough in MTG and video games because inside he's lonely and has little self worth, and is generally a bland hodpodge of geek, punk, goth, and emo subcultures.
370472: Grapeshot.text_posted:

Now that I've seen the modern interpretation of the Grapeshot artwork, representing the kind of people they want to buy their cards lately, I'm not too thrilled. *sigh*

370476: Trygon Predator.author: DarthParallax

I am usually not partial to the kinds of Simic Decks that work in EDH. Basically the point of the color combination seems to be to reject Vorthos in favor of Spike.

But, I would play this card in a Riku-Colored Deck, and maybe a Karador one as well. :) Don't know whether I'd play it in Rafiq or not.

I'm not questioning the card's power- I'd definitely play it in Legacy, and maybe Vintage (I don't know if it gets played there or not.) 370479: War-Spike Changeling.author: Totema
370479: War-Spike Changeling.text_parsed:
This card right here represents the issues I have with Modern Masters. They hyped it up to be "let's reprint lots of great cards in Modern format to even out card distribution". What we got was "let's reprint random parts of Lorwyn-Shadowmoor, Time Spiral, and Kamigawa blocks".

When has this guy ever been relevant? Why did they think that we needed another round of him? What qualifies him as a "modern master?"
370479: War-Spike Changeling.text_posted:
This card right here represents the issues I have with Modern Masters. They hyped it up to be "let's reprint lots of great cards in Modern format to even out card distribution". What we got was "let's reprint random parts of Lorwyn-Shadowmoor, Time Spiral, and Kamigawa blocks".

When has this guy ever been relevant? Why did they think that we needed another round of him? What qualifies him as a "modern master?"

370479: War-Spike Changeling.author: Atali
370479: War-Spike Changeling.text_parsed:
When they decided to make the set draftable, it stopped being a toolbox of modern fodder and started gaining random things like this for limited.
Kamigawa, Time Spiral, and Lorwyn-Shadowmoor blocks are heavily represented because there were relatively fewer players during those blocks, resulting in less of those cards in circulation.
370479: War-Spike Changeling.text_posted:

370479: War-Spike Changeling.author: Ferlord
370479: War-Spike Changeling.text_parsed:
To Atali and Totema:

I thought the exact same thing when I saw a few garbage cards getting printed. I thought, "ok. Well, they still have 120 more cards to spoil. I bet most of them will have seen some Modern play!". When it was fully spoiled, I was disappointed in the lack of Cycling creatures from Alara (like Deadshot Minotaur, used in Living End (and that as well)) Azusa, Heritage Druid and her pals (Nettle Sentinel etc.), and a whole slew of other choices.

However, once I got a box of it, it all hit me: this was made primarily for Limited.

On the box it says something along the lines of "Prepare for the most intense Limited Experience ever!". This implies that this was more of a reprint of cards in the previous sets that'd make for an intense limited tournament. Later that night, I played a Modern Masters draft (excluding the expensive cards) and this proved true. Who'd guess that using your Blightspeaker to for a Saltfield Recluse would turn the tides of a game?

Long story short, cards like this are exactly what makes up the majority of the set. Sure, they initially spoiled it as a set to reduce the price of them Modern staples, but if they truly wanted to do that, they'd have at least included Zendikar in their array of choosable sets.

Long story short, this card is great in limited (combat tricks on an "anything" creature? Huzzah!) and is in the right place. Had they changed the name to "Magic: 20th anniversary" or something, people wouldn't be so disappointed, but they wouldn't be buying the set.

370480: Empty the Warrens.author: TomTomat
370480: Empty the Warrens.text_parsed: I hope there comes a time when Wizards realize that CG does not look better than hand-drawn stuff.
370480: Empty the Warrens.text_posted: I hope there comes a time when Wizards realize that CG does not look better than hand-drawn stuff.

370480: Empty the Warrens.author: DarthParallax
370480: Empty the Warrens.text_parsed:
TomTomat: it is not as clear-cut as that. Look at Goblin Recruiter's original art. Frankly, it is way too crude and sucks for something that's that awesome.

Now, I will agree that I am Usually partial, lovingly, under-doggedly, to hand-drawn over digital. But I prefer this art over it's original. It feels like there's more Goblins here than there are in the Time Spiral one, and it turns out that Storm Cards have better justice done in their art when the art assumes you have a high storm count.

But I DO appreciate that the old art style is very cool and beautiful. The thing is, it's nearly dead. And with the Modern Frame, they're almost never -actually- going to look like they used to. I think, though, that they are trying to look a little bit more realistic. I don't mean 'SO-CGI-it-looks-like-World-of-Warcraft"....no, I think they're Attempting to move their Art Style more towards looking like it's coming out of high-quality Graphic Novels...a 'tad' hyper-real, but in a way where it's a little more normal for your imagination to 'go with it'.

I have to be honest, some of the Izzet art was strange this year. Being Izzet, they PULLED OFF looking a bit like World of Warcraft...and actually, hand-painted was what looked wrong for them. Blast of Genius. Or that promo of Render Silent. WAY too much Yellow.

Magic Art Style is difficult to get right- because each theme and subtheme and setting kind of wants a whole different style.

That's why I'm Glad they use tons of different artists instead of just one, and that's also why and how we get so much differences in arts- the art is almost never going to really feel consistent with itself for long.

But...IDKN, what they're doing seems to work more often than it doesn't.

370481: Peppersmoke.author: cranial.distraction
370481: Peppersmoke.text_parsed:
In MM draft, it's not hard to get 3 of these. Black removal at common is focused on giving creatures -1/-1; Peppersmoke, Dreamspoiler Witches, Festering Goblin, Drag Down.

Peppersmoke + Drag Down with Dreamspoiler Witches in play can take down a 5/5 (say, Durkwood Baloth). You'll draw a card from the Smoke and you still have a creature in play, so while it took 3 cards to pull off, you're even with your opponent on card advantage.

Lorwyn was a 286-card set with three black tribes (Faeries, Goblins, Elves). MM is a 229-card set with four limited archetypes (Fairies, Goblins, dredge, Rebels). Consequently, it's easier to get multiples of both this and the Witch in MM than it was in Lorwyn, making the Smoke-Witch combo more feasible now.

370485: Sanctum Gargoyle.author: dhinge
370485: Sanctum Gargoyle.text_parsed: So it's a Treasure Hunter with flying and an extra point of toughness... this isn't strictly better or powercreep? Does making it a Gargoyle and an artifact somehow offset the ramp?
370485: Sanctum Gargoyle.text_posted: So it's a [autocard]Treasure Hunter[/autocard] with flying and an extra point of toughness... this isn't strictly better or powercreep? Does making it a Gargoyle and an artifact somehow offset the ramp?

370485: Sanctum Gargoyle.author: Minus_Prime
370485: Sanctum Gargoyle.text_parsed:
Well dhinge, it's normally agreed that being an artifact is neither better nor worse than the alternatives because there are plenty of situations where that property can be a boon or a hindrance. So whether an 'artifact creature' is better in that case depends on your deckbuilding skills to make optimum use of the given cards.
But I don't think the argument can be made that this Sanctum Gargoyle is a strict upgrade of, or a case of powercreep over, Treasure Hunter mostly because this vastly better card costs a total of 4 mana, compared to the other one which costs 3. You pay more to get more, which is the very first thing that must be checked before you consider nominating anything for the Strictly Awards.

370485: Sanctum Gargoyle.author: me7062a
370485: Sanctum Gargoyle.text_parsed: Minus_Prime, in this case being an artifact creature is a huge upgrade.  If you get two of them, you can infinitely recur them by playing Sanctum Gargoyle to fetch Sanctum Gargoyle (a la the ol' Gravedigger trick, who he IS almost strictly better than). Against any non-exiling removal, he pretty handily destroys limited decks all on his own since he also flies, and he's not bad in Pauper.

370489: Avian Changeling.author: psychichobo
370489: Avian Changeling.text_parsed:
Mistform Ultimus still has the Legendary thing going for it, as well as no need for paying for the Changeling ability. He does have a good EDH position (arguably not as the general mind).

What I do like about Changelings though is that they encourage players to explore a tribe via different colours. For example, you could run a White/Green Elf deck that uses this guy as aerial offence, or a White/Red Goblin deck that does similar things.

I've had great success with a Green/Black Rogue deck, since the Green Changelings give you a bit of staying power in multiplayer and adding green allows for some powerful combat tricks - it's better to get prowl via going OVER your opponent's creatures rather than around them!

370490: City of Brass.author: SkyknightXi
370490: City of Brass.text_parsed:
Worth noting: In the original Arabian Nights stories, the City of Brass was an Amalekite city that earned God's wrath and was slain in a single night...except for the queen and her bodyguards, who were somehow trapped in stasis. Just looking over the walls could drive the weak-willed into suicidal horror, and even the most strong-willed felt a pall of sorrow while walking through. Oh, and be careful about trying to go near the queen--the bodyguards will go out of stasis just long enough to kill you.

So originally, it damaged you because you're slowly suffering agonizing sorrow. Psychosomatically agonizing sorrow.

370490: City of Brass.author: DarthParallax
370490: City of Brass.text_parsed:
probably...they've honestly just been keeping it at rare because a Silver Set symbol would maybe clash a bit (albeit pleasingly) with all the gold/brass in the art. Best to leave it at a flavor-fitting Rare, if an almost mildly-underpowered one.

This card's closest comparison is Birds of Paradise. Is it better or worse?
Honestly? I don't care.

I'm playing it in every Djinn of Wishes of Deck I make. :D

And every Djinn of Wishes deck I make will include ALI FROM CAIRO. ^_^

Yes, this is how I roll, Gatherer. B|

It's underpowered, SAUS3, because the only lands REALLY worth paying life into are Shocks and Fetches. I GUESS I've seen City of Brass make 'serious' decklists, but I always thought that indicated they were building on a budget.

Compare it to the Xth Edition standard of lands: Yeah, it's Pure Gold.

Compare it to some of what we've seen in Green at common and uncommon, though? It somehow seems worse. I'd say Mox Opal gives it very stiff competition, even with the Metalcraft. I think this sort of effect is close to being "Uncommon" in the next year or so, especially considering how powerful the Guildgates are. Command Tower is technically not really any more common or rare than Sol Rings with the same expansion symbol, but they gave it a black set symbol for show. City of Brass could be uncommon if they wanted.

I think it's Rare for Limited: there's SO many goodies in this set, if it were Uncommon, Modern Masters Draft would have Colors of Decks similar to Ravnica Block Draft, only with Hyper Stupid Cards.

370490: City of Brass.author: Continue
370490: City of Brass.text_parsed: Coming soon in Journey Into Nyx: Mana Confluence. Never thought I'd see the day when they would fix City of Brass. Note that neither card is better or worse than the other; Mana Confluence simply removes a lot of confusion from the original. For example, you can tap City of Brass for while you're on 1 life and cast Lightning Bolt on top of the damage trigger to defeat an opponent on 3, or your opponent can Rishadan Port your City of Brass and repeatedly deal 1 damage to you. Having it as a life payment makes it much more intuitive. Whatever the case, I'm very excited for the new card — my Cascade Reanimator deck can finally run 8 Cities of Brass instead of just 4!

370492: Death Denied.author: DarthParallax
370492: Death Denied.text_parsed:
The new art actually looks like it's from a Space Colony, not Kamigawa....and yet I can see Kamigawa, kinda, in the Nezumi architecture. I LIKE this. It feels like it's from OLD School MAGIC, which felt twice as Sci-Fi and Philosophical as today's MAGIC story.

I like MAGIC flavor, I LOVE Agents of Artifice, but even the very height of cool flavor Post-Mending holds nothing to the blaze of flavor that once was THE MULTIVERSE, in the time of Urza Planeswalker. Urza was the Obi-Wan Kenobi that held it all together and made it WORK. Magic used to be like....like Star Trek crossed with Star Wars crossed with Pastoral Symphony from Fantasia. Da da da DA dadada duh duh Duh DUH dadada....Stormfront Pegasus anyone? :P Lightning Bolt? :P

Ah, forget about it.


There are too many stories now. Too many Planeswalkers, but no Central Hero. If it's Jace, actually show some things happening to him. Actually get him to bring a New Coalition together against Bolas. You've been putting it off too long, Wizards. I will be watching for Multiversal stories in Theros block very carefully.

370493: Reveillark.author: Trygon_Predator
370493: Reveillark.text_parsed:
You want to play this with Mirror Entity, Body Double, and your pick of a creature with <2 power and an ETB ability.

It's an involved combo. In short, the Body Double copies the Reveillark and keeps bringing itself and the ETB creature back, as often as you like. Mirror Entity gets the ball rolling by stacking 0/0 activations.

Some simple combo pieces: Cathedral Sanctifier for infinite life, Riftwing Cloudskate to bounce permanents, Ghitu Slinger to deal damage, Mulldrifter for massive card draw...

370493: Reveillark.author: MisterAction
370493: Reveillark.text_parsed:
I very rarely evoke this. Since it triggers not on dying, but on leaving the battlefield, it's a huge deterrent not just to attacking but to pretty much any sweeper as well. It can really only be shut down by Mind Control or Pacifism (and in the latter case, you're just going to flicker it anyway).

This can be very annoying to see on the other end of the field because it's privy to a huge number of instakill combos, but when used responsibly it's a fun, powerful and exciting card. 5/5

370497: Epochrasite.author: Mode
370497: Epochrasite.text_parsed:
"Why oh why couldn't it be a common now? I want to Unearth it in Pauper :)"

@Earthdawn They want to keep their Commons simple.
Epocharasite is probably considered too complex as a Common card:
It gets counters, but only if it's not cast normally. It gets suspended when it dies, which means it needs to be taken care of with yet another kind of counters in exile each turn...

If every Common required that much attention, Drafts would get a lot less straight-forward.
Then again, there are a couple of similar exceptions, and it doesn't hurt if only about 1% of the Commons are like this.

Admittedly, i'd have like the idea at least as much as you do, even if only for the fact that jumps from Rare to Common and vice versa are hilarious. (Thinking of another, very particular 1/1 for two mana - that actually managed to pull off in both directions.)

370504: Ethersworn Canonist.author: blurrymadness
370504: Ethersworn Canonist.text_parsed:
This is not for late-game. This is for anti-combo unless you're running artifacts. It's also for things like Zoo, Goblins, or similar, who may try to play loads of spells while you meander up your curve.

Even so, every deck, be it artifacts or not; want this out T1-T2 if they're going to play it. You want to stuff the opponent's tempo if he's going to go that route. It helps for making people decide between removal or more creatures in aggro decks (as they may even want to use instant speed removal on their turn in order to clear blockers.)

370504: Ethersworn Canonist.author: ShatterPalm
370504: Ethersworn Canonist.text_parsed: I think this is less of a Gaddock Teeg and more of a miniature teferi, Mage of zhalfir. She doesn't prevent higher card drops but rather makes sure that your opponents ( and to a lesser extent her controller) ensure that they make it count when they cast spells. I've seen and won counter wars over this thing and believe me when she's on your field you practically have soft lock. With the isochron scepter on the field and some form of counter or bounce underneath it they basically won't be able to do anything. Just make sure they can't pay for a mana leak.

370506: Reach Through Mists.author: Hepatizon
370506: Reach Through Mists.text_parsed:
The reason for this card vs. Serum Visions or Ponder or any of the others is simply that it's an instant and an arcane. You can cast it on your opponent's turn in order to splice something else, and you get a card. Outside of splice decks, not great. In splice decks--as well as decks that have effects that trigger when you draw a card--quite handy.

I personally think arcane is great and underutilized. It was big in Kamigawa, but Wizards was just way too cautious with that block and it suffered from major Mercadian Masques syndrome, so much of it being lackluster in power and potential compared to other blocks. Still, many of its cards and mechanics manage to endure. I would love to see it tied in with wizard tribal at some point, I would have thought Izzet would be the ideal group to pick it up both thematically and mechanically.

But alas, it was not to be, and I've rambled on. It's a mediocre card if all you want to do is draw a card, but it's a decent card if you're comboing it.

The advantage with Splice spells lies in the ability to cast more spells through a single card, though - double Glacial Ray spliced onto this is quite good for the cost, and could potentially be a 2 for 0 (burn two creatures and replace Reach with a new card) at instant speed for 5 mana - and then you've still got two Glacial Rays in your hand to cast again later.

370507: Stir the Pride.author: Mode
370507: Stir the Pride.text_parsed:
Why is Auriok Salvagers a Rare in Modern Masters, yet this is an Uncommon?

Imho, when they were to give one white Uncommon from Mirrodin a Rarity boost in that set, they should have gone with Stir The Pride instead.
This card has great potential in any creature-heavy deck and is especially nice in casual.
I remember some of my earlier games against my cousin's altered Swarm and Slam deck, and i lost more than once against him, thanks to that card - and when that happened, he usually ended up with 50 or more life.

This would have been a nice casual Timmy rare, and would have certainly made more people happy than those getting Auriok Salvagers in their rare slot - while at the same time neither of them would have gotten any notable value change.

Then again, Auriok Salvagers might got the rare slot instead so that he wouldn't show up as many times as this card.

370510: Arcbound Ravager.text_parsed:
WOW!!!!!!

this, now, a RARE, instead of a Foil Mythic like Maze of Ith, in an actual draft set so you can get it Foil for Bling OR Non Foil for Cheap, making it THE STRICTLY BEST Reprint in M:TG history and it STILL lost it's 5/5 on Gatherer?

Go to hell, internet -_- You don't deserve Kev Walker artworks. :'(

Anyone complaining about devalued collections Or about overpriced MM booster packs: This could have been a Mythic, or it could have been Not In MM and it would slowly creep out of range as casual demand makes it impossible for casual players to afford, and then as more and more cards get on the 'not reserved but we still aren't giving it to you' list, Magic just dies a sad death because Legacy, Vintage, and Modern become Proxy-only Formats.

Or, what actually happened, which was this.
This is the biggest birthday present of Magic's 20 Year Anniversary, unless Jace is in FTV: 20..

Dredge, Affinity, and Storm are the most broken mechanics of All Get Out, and within a year we've had a Non-Mythic Golgari Grave-Troll, a Non-Mythic Arcbound Ravager, and a Non-Mythic Dragonstorm. And the Fetchlands and Shocklands are still valuable investments but more affordable than Beta Duals by an extravagantly good deal for such functional interchangeability. WOTC cares. WOTCS cares A LOT. Say No to WOTC-haters.

370510: Arcbound Ravager.author: Totema
370510: Arcbound Ravager.text_parsed:
Hmm. Is its ruling obsolete?

420.5n: If a permanent has both a +1/+1 counter and a -1/-1 counter on it, N +1/+1 and N -1/-1 counters are removed from it, where N is the smaller of the number of +1/+1 and -1/-1 counters on it.

In other words, getting -1/-1 counters would remove that many +1/+1 counters. Did they make a mistake, or is this some crazy rules interaction thanks to Modular?

370510: Arcbound Ravager.author: Ferlord
370510: Arcbound Ravager.text_parsed:
The thing I like about this is that the art depicts what a 20/20 Ravager looks like after it nom'ed all of your Great Furnace's, Ornithopter's, Frogmite's, and Memnite's. Also known as it's primary use.

In non-competitive formats (EDH particularly), this acts as a Greater Gargodon. Someone Naturalize's your Sol Ring?
Well, first you say "Well F**K you, you a-hole. You know what? I was thinking of using my Wrath of God for when my friend next to me plays Kaalia of the Vast. But since you think having an additional mana in my mana pool will make me less of a threat, you've just become 'that guy'. I'm now going to focus all of my energy and effort on you. Let it be known that once you are dead, I will concede. Oh and by the way, I have an Iona, Shield of Emeria in my hand. I wasn't going to play it since it's such a buzz-kill in EDH, but now you've forced my hand. Oh? You're only playing Green? Absolutely delicious...",
... and then you sacrifice the Sol Ring to Ravager.

370510: Arcbound Ravager.author: MostlyLost
370510: Arcbound Ravager.text_parsed:
Reasons why this card is stupid (in the best possible way):
1. Its ability is free, non-tap, and instant, so you can use it the turn it hits the field.
2. It drops for two colorless. Two freaking colorless.
3. Its ability is free, non-tap, and instant, meaning you can use it the in response to a kill spell (or any spell really).
4. It can sac itself.
5. Its ability is free, non-tap, and instant, meaning you can sac things that want to be sacced (like Myr Retriever or something else with modular).
6. Drew into a Mox Opal when you already have one out? Float the mana, sac it, then play the other one.
7. Its ability is free, non-tap, and instant, making for crazy combat tricks. Shift all your power to the unblocked attacker, or put the counters on Blinkmoth Nexus or Ichorclaw Myr if you want to lose friends.
8. It says "Sacrifice an artifact." Not "artifact creature", not "another artifact", just "artifact."
9. Its ability is free, non-tap, and instant. I think I mentioned that already, though.

Yeah. 6/5.

370510: Arcbound Ravager.author: thispersonisagenius
370510: Arcbound Ravager.text_parsed:
Arcbound Ravager can allow turn 3 wins in Modern with a bit of luck:

Opening Hand: 3x Memnite/Ornithopter, Inkmoth Nexus, Arcbound Ravager, Mox Opal, Darksteel Citadel

Turn 1: Play all of the zero cost artifact creatures, followed by Inkmoth Nexus into Mox Opal into Arcbound Ravager.

Turn 2: Play Darksteel Citadel, use it to activate Inkmoth Nexus and attack. Sacrifice all your artifacts except for the Inkmoth Nexus and Darksteel Citadel to Arcbound Ravager, then sacrifice Arcbound Ravager to put at least five (if you drew an additional 1 mana artifact to cast with Mox Opal, cast and sacrifice that as well if you'd like) +1/+1 counters on the Inkmoth Nexus to get your opponent to at least 6 poison counters.

Turn 3: Use Darksteel Citadel to activate Inkmoth Nexus and swing your opponent up to at least 12 poison counters.

What a sweet card.

370511: Greater Mossdog.author: DarthParallax
370511: Greater Mossdog.text_parsed:
There's really no reason to play this card. It's 4 mana for a 3/3, which is terrible in Red, let alone Green. It's passable in Black and Blue though.

And it only Dredges for 3. It'll never make the cut in any Dredge deck, even in limited, because Stinkweed Imp is also a common, and just so much better, and Golgari Thug should be your #2 man.

It's a card with no real home except unlucky Limited decks that didn't pull the good Dredge cards.

4/5 stars because Dredge is Retarded. Retardedly Awesome. ^_^

370514: Aether Vial.author: DarthParallax
370514: Aether Vial.text_parsed:
From the Vault Reprints are always Mythics. Kokusho is a Mythic now. On a scale of 1-5, 1 and 2 being "Rare", 4 and 5 being "Mythic", Kokusho is about a 3.5 to me if you are playing with all the bannings and rules changes in place. Sure, when you combo 4 of them to kill someone outright, I guess that's pretty Mythic. I don't think you're allowed to do that anywhere where it's relevant, though.

Demonic Tutor would be a Mythic Rare if was in From the Vault. If it was reprinted somewhere else, it would probably be a Rare, though.
Aethervial is VERY comparable to Tinker and Demonic Tutor.
They're all broken-in-a-million pieces uncommons that could be either Mythics or Rares, depending on if you are talking Draft or Constructed.

Aethervial and Arcbound Ravager aren't Mythics because WOTC thought it would be more fun this way, with a Mythic Ryusei and Jugan and Rare Crazy Awesome Stuff. I am inclined to agree with them. I don't think Aethervial's value will ''actually'' crash, and here's why:

The Commander Sol Rings are at a respectable $10ish once again, and the FTV foil one is not too far away from a very unshabby $20. I think Sol Ring is in a position for EDH like the Shock Lands are for Modern- deliberately staggered periodic rereleases. However I think Aethervial has just about had it's last huzzah unless they Judge it with pimped old frame or something. Aethervial will go down temporarily, go back up, (just like Sol Ring so far) and then, because it is not crucial for every single player to own one, it will not get reprinted anytime soon. I'd grab the VAULT ones now while you can. :)

370514: Aether Vial.author: EGarrett01
370514: Aether Vial.text_parsed:
I actually wish Wizards would let us give several separate ratings to cards, since people use different criteria.

It would be cool if each card had a separate meter for Power, Fun (or Balance), and Flavor. That way cards like Vial, Baneslayer, Jace and Mishra's Workshop could be super-high on power and rated horribly on balance/fun, and cards like Nicol Bolas and Form of the Dragon could be perfect on fun or flavor, and the true greatest cards would have to deliver in all three areas, like Isochron Scepter.

I think everyone would be happier that way.

370514: Aether Vial.author: blurrymadness
370514: Aether Vial.text_parsed:
The instant speed on this is the difference between Spirit of the labyrinth being decent and being insane. Same can be said for Phyrexian Revoker and Flickerwisp.

It also turns insane cards into nigh-unanswerable cards; Dark Confidant, Stoneforge, etc..


That said, I think people who bash the balance on this love blue too much. This is a very powerful card, but at the cost of it being very useless by itself and a terrible topdeck. It's build-around to a degree; even if it doesn't look that way. Learning to use it optimally is also a bit of a learning curve on the best creatures.

370517: Arcbound Worker.author: Mode
370517: Arcbound Worker.text_parsed:
It's a decent choice.
And i mean this both in regards of the players as well as Wizards:
It's a nice inclusion in Modern Masters, and it's a nice pick in draft.


(Modern Masters Alternate Card Inclusion Rant)
However, if there's one little thing i missed in Modern Masters, it would have been Myr Servitor.

I'd have prefered Myr Servitor over him because he already got a reprint recently with an up-to-date Oracle in the Elspeth vs. Tezzeret Duel Deck. Of course that alone wouldn't justify that idea.
Also there's an Arcbound subtheme going on in MM, so they couldn't simply drop the little one(/one) either way.

The Myr wouldn't be as useful as this guy in draft, but still a good choice simply for being a colorless one-drop after all.
Also i'm talking as if including the Myr automatically meant excluding the Worker. There would probably have been some way to cram it in otherwise.

Admittedly the Myr isn't a notable choice for competitive decks.
But then again, Modern Masters wasn't designed to exclusively include the most playable cards for Modern imaginable, regarding the Commons anyway.

Still, I would really have liked an updated reprint of this Myr - and i might be wrong, but i can imagine quite a couple of other players that thought the same way.
It's one of the more popular cards of that type that screams to build a deck around - and Modern happens to be one of the greatest formats for such experiments since it's an eternal format, so you'll always be able to draw from a great and ever-growing pool of cards, while simultaneously excluding the barely accessible and borderline ridiculous cards, thus not having a power level quite as crazy as Legacy, let alone Vintage. Which is why i'd have liked to have it here :P

370521: Maelstrom Pulse.author: Ferlord
370521: Maelstrom Pulse.text_parsed:
I can clearly see a "pulse" ripping through the land in this art. I believe this is also the Judge Promo art. Is this better than the previous art? It's really hard to say, but if it came down to it, I'd say this one is better.

So what can be said about Maelstrom Pulse?
It's reason number 2 why is one of the most popular EDH colours (Reasons 1 being Pernicious Deed).
It can target almost any permanent (I wonder which it can't target... if only it were obvious...).
It can be just as effective as a sorcery-speed Naturalize, or just as damning as a completely one-sided Damnation.
It has the ability to kill Planeswalkers.
If there are two copies of one permanent where one is untargetable, you can target the targetable one to kill the other.
It's cheap enough to play competitively but expensive and colour-heavy enough where people don't complain about it.

It may be one of the most perfect cards in Magic.

370522: Glen Elendra Archmage.author: Xycolian
370522: Glen Elendra Archmage.text_parsed:
Let's go over the perks of this card, shall we?


1. You are free to attack with this as long as nothing can block it (notice how it's ability does not require it to tap).

1(a) Seeing as it's ability does not require it to tap, it can effectively counter something the moment it comes into play (provided you have the mana of course).

2. You get 2+ counters out of it for only 1 card slot being taken up in your deck count.

3. It messes with you opponents head, and their tempo. They will need to waste at least 2 removal spells on it before they can slip their big spell through, and by then you should have other answers for it.

4. If you are running simic, power conduit, or any other counter shenanigans concurrently with this card, you pretty much win the game (as long as your opponent's deck isn't creture centric - but there's other counterspells for that)

5. It ends most counterspell wars. Since it's an ability, only a select few abilities/spells can counter it. So if you're in a control mirror match, it can give you an unfair advantage (if you manage to get it out in the first place that is).

370522: Glen Elendra Archmage.author: Zefyrus
370522: Glen Elendra Archmage.text_parsed:
She's a wizard, along with other Faerie wizards, so combine it with Riptide Laboratory and BAM, you've got this honey recurring all the time. Plus, making it REALLY hard to be removed.
1st removal spell -> Counter it with her ability.
2nd removal spell as response -> Use Riptide Laboratory's ability and return it to your hand.
So the opponent will think about it even more before wasting spells to remove her.
If you run her in a Vendilion Clique / Snapcaster Mage white/blue control deck like me, she adds that extra board pressure (that control decks usually have plenty) and if used correctly, the ability to lock games for a short while, until you win.

5/5

370523: Arcbound Wanderer.author: Ferlord
370523: Arcbound Wanderer.text_parsed:
The more obvious problem with this is that Modular only helps artifact creatures. For this to be used to its fullest, you need to be playing a lot of artifact creatures AND multiple colours. Although the Vivid lands were printed, getting anywhere more than 3 colours is going to be a chore.

In limited, 3 colours isn't that odd to play around. However, sometimes you just can't get that 3rd land, and are stuck playing with just 2 of your 3 colours, even on turn six. What do you do then? Do you make a 2/2 for , or do you wait until the next turn, hoping to get that 3rd colour? It's just one of the problems of Limited that you have to work around. Empty the Warrens works just the same: do you wait for a cheap spell to add on 2 more tokens, or just work with 2 1/1 tokens for ?

All in all, this is either above average or absolutely worthless.

370525: Thirst for Knowledge.author: Zylo-
370525: Thirst for Knowledge.text_parsed:
@Continue

The reason this is restricted in Vintage because of the interaction it has with other power cards in that format.... Thirst for Knowledge is guilty by association with such Vintage one-hit-wonders as Ancestral Recall and Brainstorm. Plus, it has the added bonus of fuelling the caster’s graveyard for future exploitation by Yawgmoth’s Will or Goblin Welder.

It doesn't have nearly the same power in Modern which is why it is legal. Calling a card powerful in modern due to it's mechanics with cards in vintage format is irrelevant...

It's a decent card but... There are better options in modern for 3cmc...

The main reason this card is good is because it is searchable with Trinket Mage and Artificer's Intuition. Artifacts are also a lot easier to reuse and recurse with cards like Auriok Salvagers and Salvaging Station. For all these reasons Dispeller's Capsule has far more utility than other disenchant variants, and maybe that's why activation cost is increased.

Mind you, these cards are most likely to only show up in an EDH deck such as Sharuum, the Hegemon.

370528: Lightning Helix.author: Lifegainwithbite
370528: Lightning Helix.text_parsed:
@Tinderbundler: Let's see. If you're at 1 or 2 life and draw Searing Spear, how much is it going to do? You can kill one of your opponents' creatures but if they've gotten you to 1 or 2 life, they're probably going to kill you. Lightning Helix buys you time, perhaps enough time to draw an answer - another burn spell or a big creature that could save you. Plus they cost exactly the same amount. It's just pure card advantage. Why go for the worse option if you're running those colours?

A much fairer comparison is to Lightning Bolt where Helix does fall a bit short but in many situations, it can still be better. It's overall a fantastic card. The 3 life doesn't always come in handy but when it does, it'll really save you.

When I was newer to the game I thought this was absolute trash (way begore the reprint) and it took a lot of experience with the game before I understood that in fast-paced decks this can read "UU, exile some cards from your graveyard: counter target spell". Because it needs the graveyard as fuel to be really effective I wouldn't recommend it in slower decks, and I would advise against running more than two in most decks. That said, I'm a huge fan of this card.

370530: Earwig Squad.author: Krenkowned
370530: Earwig Squad.text_parsed:
A great card in goblin or rogue tribal deck. Rogues and goblins should both be able to get an attacker through by turn 3 worst case scenario. A 5/3 with Jester's Cap ability on turn 3 is not to be scoffed at. The card is amazing in EDH, removing combo pieces, major threats, or anything else that might ruin your day. Cards like Frogtosser Banneret and Goblin Warchief allow you to play this card for just 2 or even 1 mana!

Not to say that there aren't more degenerate, mean, and broken things you can do with Goblin Lackey, but cheating one of the aforementioned lords onto the battlefield, and casting Earwig Squad for is a pretty efficient turn. While being extremely powerful, the card is mostly useless outside its tribal groups if you can't cast it for its prowl cost, which probably explains its mediocre rating. Even so, this thing is a boss in my Wort, Boggart Auntie EDH deck.

370531: Careful Consideration.author: jonrds
370531: Careful Consideration.text_parsed:
I feel like this is better than the rating suggests. Compare it to Fact or Fiction. You dig 1 less card down and net 1 or 2 cards instead of 2-3 (occasionally 1 or 4, but thats rare), but you get to choose exactly how the hand/graveyard split happens. You can keep the best cards and ditch any 2-3 from your hand that need to be in the graveyard.

It may not be better, especially with that extra blue in the casting cost, but it is definitely closer than the rating implies.

370533: Auntie's Snitch.text_parsed:
A 3/1 for 2 is on curve for goblins, being able to recur is a nice advantage, especially with Goblin Warrens. You have tokens so you can get this guy back. You have sacrifice fodder so you can create more tokens. It's a vicious cycle :)

Note that he can attack with Warren Instigator and legion loyalist, do his damage, be sacrificed to altar's reap, and be played again on Warren's trigger or on your own mana for prowl

Janky, but sounds fun

370534: Kiki-Jiki, Mirror Breaker.author: Mode
370534: Kiki-Jiki, Mirror Breaker.text_parsed:
"And they told me Kamigawa Block was bad..."

@chainsmoker Sorry for being that guy, but it admittedly was if about 6% of the cards were great, 1% was broken,
33% were decent and yet about 60% was somewhere between "meh" and downright terrible.

It had various great rares and a couple of memorable uncommons like Ghostly Prison or Hinder,
but there also were lots of weak cards.

Yeah, Kamigawa wasn't as bad as some make it out to be.

But i can understand those that didn't like that block because, sadly, none of the most memorable cards from this set were related to any of the actual themes this set had - (Splice onto) Arcane, Soulshift, Spiritcraft, Epic, Channel, Sweep, and Wisdom are all keywords that are barely remembered, or at least barely saw tournament play.
Sure, there were a couple of good cards for each keyword.
But none of the competetive decks specified in any of those themes.

Most of the Spirit and Arcane cards in particular - which made up a major part of the whole set - bear a lot of wasted potential.
And all of Saviors of Kamigawa's minor themes were rather underwhelming.
Don't get me wrong, it brought us some great cards (just like CoK or BoK) - there's Twincast, Erayo, Pithing Needle, Kataki, War's Wage, Promise of Bunrei, and some good uncommons like Hand of Honor and Hand of Cruelty...

But if the core part of the block that makes it unique - the special themes - is forgettable, then so is the block itself.

I do like many cards of the block - Kiki-Jike here included.
I was also quite excited about most ideas Wiards came up with. But it was the execution that left me hanging...

Then again, Kamigawa came right after the Mirrodin block, and with that some of the most ridiculously broken decks in Standard in years. So my guess is, Wizards simply tweaked the majority of their cards a bit too much at that time, to make sure they wouldn't repreat that mistake immediately again.

When a new player looks at that p/t and 5 mana, it's heaven when they think "why on earth..?"

370537: Dragonstorm.author: Technetium
370537: Dragonstorm.text_parsed:
The irony of this card is that it takes a lot of ramping to be able to cast it early enough in the game to matter, which means you will have a fairly high storm count when cast, and yet you only need a count of 3 to win.

I haven't seen much mention of it, but the essential dragon is definitely Karrthus, Tyrant of Jund. You want to be able to pull it off with the minimal storm count possible as well as not having to give your opponent a turn. The 2nd most important creature is the Bogardan Hellkite because, assuming you also have Karrthus out, it's 10 damage. For the remaining 3 damage, nearly anything else will do.

370543: Adarkar Valkyrie.author: DarthParallax
370543: Adarkar Valkyrie.text_parsed:
Doaj- actually, Modern Masters was a great dumping place for it. Modern Masters is not supposed to be the next Commander's Arsenal (ie- intended as a gift to a 'casual' crowd that ends up being priced out of the range of everyone who wants it).

I could see this card in A Commander Deck, in Modern Masters, or in a Duel Deck.

Modern Masters shaped up to be a place where they put a whole bunch of Time Spiral and Coldsnap reprints, so I'm glad to see it. :) The rares of this set are a beautiful mix of 'playable but not Super Bomb' and 'whoah. they reprinted THAT?'

We got a non-Mythic Arcbound Ravager, I don't want to hear any complaints. Flavorwise, the Kami-Dragons deserve Mythic Rarity. This will hugely help people acquire masses of packs and maybe bust one Bob, Goyf, or Clique.

WOTC did not screw this one up. They weren't able to put all the goodies in one bag. Thinking in terms of having two bags to put goodies into was great long-term strategy thinking!

3 stars- I won't pretend this card is any worse or better than it is.

370543: Adarkar Valkyrie.author: Ferlord

One of the ugliest cards to see in a multi-player EDH game. If you pop a Oblivion Stone with a counter on it, or if it bypasses a boardwipe (like Divine Reckoning), you can always return your opponents stuff to your side.

Mind you, this doesn't bypass shroud/hexproof (as I initially thought; I thought the ability was "return a creature put into grave this turn"). Yet another reason why Glaring Spotlight should/could be in every EDH deck.

Totally not obvious Pro Tip: Attack with this first, then resurrect!

370544: Countryside Crusher.author: TheMurderousKitten
370544: Countryside Crusher.text_parsed:
@Buderus:

That combo with Library of Leng wouldn't work. The first ruling listed on Library of Leng specifically says that "This effect has no effect on the cards being put into the graveyard from a library, because they are not 'discarded.'" In other words, the Library won't let you retrieve the cards sent to the graveyard by the Crusher. And even if that ruling didn't exist, it still wouldn't work, because the Crusher's ability only triggers when the land card actually hits the graveyard, which the Library prevents from happening. It's a nice thought to combine the two, but it just wouldn't work.
370544: Countryside Crusher.text_posted:

370544: Countryside Crusher.author: r2d2go
370544: Countryside Crusher.text_parsed:
A few people seem to be confused as to why this is a 4/5 rare. Allow me to clarify.

First, the body. 3/3 for 3 is already on curve, but if you run 24 lands, pretty standard for a red aggro, you have on average +.66/+.66 each turn (look up how to add infinite series to see why), putting this a step above curve.

Second, you can combo this with a number of things. As mentioned, Scouting Trek gives him hilarious pump, Seismic Assault has good synergy, Knight of the Reliquary in Naya is also nice. His combo potential is high, and in the least common color for combos (in my opinion) as well.

Third, he lets you filter your deck. This is probably the most important one, as it means red aggro can reliably get out 3 lands and then never get more, which is exactly what it wants. Additionally, if you build around him and similar cards, you can build with a abnormally high number of lands, giving you a much more focused deck.

370548: Jhoira of the Ghitu.author: Rootkit9208
370548: Jhoira of the Ghitu.text_parsed:
This is what Izzet colors should do, speed up the game with Big risk = Big rewards tactics.
Don't think suspending your bomb for four turns is a big risk? Let's break it down.

Even with Ramp, the soonest this lovely lady can come out is turn 2. You won't be able to suspend until turn three due to mana shortage, meaning your bomb won't hit the field until turn 7 or later, giving your opponent around a quarter of their deck to go through to look for an answer to the incoming bomb without any additional card draw, tutors, etc.

Lastly, keep in mind that the suspended bomb can be seen at all times and will not surprise your opponent(s) in any way, shape, or form. God forbid you miss your upkeep trigger with suspend and be forced into leaving a time counter on it.

That said, risk is what makes Magic fun to me, and I love this lass's flavor. 5/5

370549: Engineered Explosives.author: Ferlord
370549: Engineered Explosives.text_parsed:
I was playing a person in a Modern Masters draft where I was going Jund goblins and he was going Esper control (all to a degree; Understand how little you can control what your strategy is in limited)

In the first game, I storm'ed off 2 of my 3 Empty the Warrens each for 6 1/1's (totalling 12). I ended the game with a Tromp the Domains.

Suffice to say, I didn't win the match when he sideboarded in this and got it out turn 1 each time. Do note that he also pulled 3 Echoing Truth's...

370550: Vedalken Dismisser.author: leingodf8
370550: Vedalken Dismisser.text_parsed:
Some people haven't played Ravnica limited. While I don't think it will be quite as high a pick as it was in Ravnica, this thing is such an amazing tempo swing. You get rid of their most relevant blocker, you force them to have to spend their next turn playing it out again, you advance your own board position with a, small but still useful body, and get a chance to build up your board presence again while they're still trying to play back out the same guy.

They didn't print it in modern masters without reason. You have no idea how much better this is than it looks in a draft format.

370551: Elspeth, Knight-Errant.author: DarthParallax
370551: Elspeth, Knight-Errant.text_parsed:
Take away the Core Sets and Garruk ties with Elspeth.

Garruk is one of the "Original Five". If we take away Lorwyn instead on the basis of non-Mythicness, then count both of his Core Sets, he scrapes out one extra print than Elspeth.

Elspeth is fantastically better than Garruk, and the conversation ends there.

For the Lowryn 5, either take away their Core Set Appearances, or take away their Lorwyn Appearance. This subtracts either 1 or 2 from the count, depending on how tough you want to be on them.

None of the Lorwyn 5 were impressive in a -multitude- of formats, consistently, except Jace Beleren, I believe. They've each had their moments, but I think it's something like:

Chandra Sucks.
Liliana is Fantastic (in EDH only)
Ajani and Garruk are both Good.
Jace is Dumb.

Elspeth, Knight-Errant, of the Great Walkers, is reprinted more except for Jace Beleren. And Little Jace needs to re-apply for Greatness. He might still have it, but, you know, those Rules Changes...

Karn Liberated may yet get a Duel Deck and/or a Core Reprint. Or a Commander print. Karn has okay odds of getting printed as much as Elspeth.

But Karn Liberated, Jace, the Mind Sculptor, and Elspeth, Knight-Errant are only competing against each other really, not against the others. So far Elspeth is in the lead among them, and probably guaranteed to always be ahead of Darth Jace.

370551: Elspeth, Knight-Errant.author: Shiizu
370551: Elspeth, Knight-Errant.text_parsed:
Probably one of the first planeswalkers to show us why the planeswalker type is so good. This card is paid for only once and then it proceeds to get out of hand. Every turn churning out another token or creating a new good attack while you're still playing other cards.

And if they don't deal with Elspeth, she'll deal with them. Her ultimate is really hard to deal with.

Elspeth is also a special case amongst planeswalkers: She's one of the very few who are almost always useful. If you're behind you'll generate chumps, if you're ahead or at parity she'll easily put your opponent under massive pressure. Even on curve this card is still pretty crazy.

370551: Elspeth, Knight-Errant.author: Lifegainwithbite
370551: Elspeth, Knight-Errant.text_parsed:
@Laguz: LOTV has reusable removal and will always 2 for 1 your opponent. She comes in, kills something and forces your opponent to attack her because if they don't, her +1 can really lock down the game and she threatens to kill more creatures. Liliana is great when you're behind on board position while Elspeth is better when you're ahead. Liliana's method of protecting herself is way stronger than Elspeth's even if she loses loyalty in the process. Plus costing 1 less is a big advantage, considering 4 drops are generally much better than 3 drops. Elspeth won't always 2 for 1 your opponent and Liliana always will.

Liliana dominates modern and legacy and Elspeth barely sees any play (and is much less expensive) so the argument is very much on Liliana's side.

370551: Elspeth, Knight-Errant.author: Kragash
370551: Elspeth, Knight-Errant.text_parsed:
"LOTV has reusable removal and will always 2 for 1 your opponent. She comes in, kills something and forces your opponent to attack her because if they don't, her +1 can really lock down the game and she threatens to kill more creatures."

Interesting way to look at it... but that scenario makes her into an expensive Edict to cast with the added bonus that she wins you a turn if they feel forced to kill her.

It really comes down to the deck the planeswalkers are in, the format they're being played in, and meta...
LotV is good in specific decks. Especially so in decks where she was once a free Edict on a cascade trigger.
Elspeth is just generally good and could fit in just about any white deck.

Turn 2: Play Desperate Ritual, Splice Glacial Ray. Using the mana generated by the ritual, cast Glacial Ray. Use the remaining R to perhaps suspend Rift Bolt.

370552: Glacial Ray.text_posted: Can't I just cast a [autocard]Shock [/autocard]and a [autocard]Lightning Bolt[/autocard] on the second turn, doing the same amount of damage, with the same amount of cards, without being undone by a single [autocard]counterspell[/autocard]?

370552: Glacial Ray.author: Minus_Prime
370552: Glacial Ray.text_parsed:
Majin, the point of Splice is that you can reuse the spliced card repeatedly without it leaving your hand. If you have five mana, a Lava Spike and two Glacial Rays, you cast the spike and splice both rays like this:

Lava Ray
Sorcery
Lava Ray deals 3 damage to target player.
Lava Ray deals 2 damage to target creature or player.
Lava Ray deals 2 damage to target creature or player.

7 damage, up to 3 targets, but only one card spent. You still have both rays in your hand to cast or splice again later. "Later" being:

Double Ray
Instant
Double Ray deals 2 damage to target creature or player.
Double Ray deals 2 damage to target creature or player.

and then you still have a Glacial Ray left in your hand.
370552: Glacial Ray.text_posted:
Majin, the point of Splice is that you can reuse the spliced card repeatedly without it leaving your hand. If you have five mana, a [autocard]Lava Spike[/autocard] and two [autocard]Glacial Ray[/autocard]s, you cast the spike and splice both rays like this: 

Lava Ray [2RRR]
Sorcery
Lava Ray deals 3 damage to target player.
Lava Ray deals 2 damage to target creature or player.
Lava Ray deals 2 damage to target creature or player. 

7 damage, up to 3 targets, but only one card spent. You still have both rays in your hand to cast or splice again later. "Later" being:

Double Ray [2RR]
Instant
Double Ray deals 2 damage to target creature or player.
Double Ray deals 2 damage to target creature or player.

and then you [i]still[/i] have a Glacial Ray left in your hand.

370557: Krosan Grip.author: ElliotSternberg
370557: Krosan Grip.text_parsed:
This card should be in EVERY EDH deck containing Green. If you can't find room for it, you're not looking hard enough.

It is sometimes the only card able to stop infinite combos, or protect yours. Are you about to go crazy with your graveyard shenanigans but the Tormod's Crypt on the board is stopping you? Krosan Grip's got your back.

Is your opponent playing Phage the Untouchable from gen-zone or graveyard using Sundial of the infinite to avoid the loss at a naturalize? Krosan Grip and win. (True story.)

There's a ton of other places and uses for it, but whoever decides not to play this in their green deck is being silly. It's ridiculously cheap and crazy powerful. Buy a play set and you'll never regret it. Win/5

@Atali: From etmyonline - what dinosaur means -

1841, coined in Modern Latin by Sir Richard Owen, from comb. form of Greek deinos "terrible" (see dire) + sauros "lizard" (see -saurus). Figurative sense of "person or institution not adapting to change" is from 1952.

TL;DR - Dinosaurs ARE lizards.

Turn 4, play him and us his +1 (even if it's not relevant), +1 turn 5, -6 on turn 6 (killing Sarkhan), play a new one that turn and use the new ones +1 for game. That clock is deadly.

Fantastic synergy with Domri Rade.

Every ability just slides perfectly with the others.

+1 and +1. I drew a creature card, cast it, and give it +1/+1 and haste.

that aside, He's great for an Aggro deck especially if you steal that one guy they need to block everything you're beating them to death with. love this card.

370566: Sarkhan Vol.author: Thundermaw_Hellkite
370566: Sarkhan Vol.text_parsed:
Such an underrated card in terms of playability. This guy DEMANDS removal, or he will blow up at your face. I mean... he is not the most utility or broken planeswalker, but consider this:
- He buffs your creatures. Never a bad thing and obviously encourages aggro
- He steals your opponents creatures. Have a problem with that Eldrazi over there? Sure, its dream situation, but when it happens, you will love having this out in play.
- Finally... if your opponent doesnt seek to kill him, he brings literally 20 power to the table... in 3 turns.

Guess people do find planeswalkers with self protecting abilities more appealing, but I am sad to see this particular one so left in the dust. Not to mention the artwork is superb (kudos to Daarken)

370573: Shrapnel Blast.author: Laguz
370573: Shrapnel Blast.text_parsed:
This is one of the cards that made Mirrodin block one of the most poorly designed blocks ever, if not THE worst. I'm talking from a designer's standpoint, of course. Mirrodin was basically waiting to see who drew the 4th shrapnel blast first. Along with Isochron Scepter, skullclamp, arcbound ravager and a few other design fails, Mirrodin sent players running for the hills in droves. I personally didn't return to magic until Ravnica.

Two mana for 5 instant speed damage in a set that rendered its drawback null and void. What else needs to be said.

If so, did that guy try to chew that trinket or something?

Alternatively, the idea of a red mage being able to make any artifact (like that metal plate hat contraption)
explode just by... i don't know, snipping with his fingers, seems a bit overpowered.

There would have beeen a plethora of concepts for artwork that would have fitted better.
But i'll give it that: if there's something it does deliver that's true to this spell, it's the severe pain it causes.

Still, i could imagine plenty of better opportunities for a literal bloody mind blow as artwork choice.

@Laguz You forgot Æther Vial :P

370574: Yosei, the Morning Star.text_parsed:

How is it a flying yoshi? I think the art is fine.
